number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												First of all, I'd like to give a shoutout and thank a couple of friends of mine from allowing me to enjoy this game. One of them for getting me into this franchise and the other one for gifting me this game when it was on sale. I'm not gonna make any mentions, but they know who they are!Now, Hyperdimension Neptunia... I remember seeing this game back as a PS3 exclusive, a few years ago. But I didn't feel like playing it and I couldn't buy it cuz I didn't have a PS3 at the time and the one thing to get my attention where the main characters on the cover. So this was my first shot at it.For starters, the story. And I'll try to talk about it here without spoiling too much, here. The game takes place in Gamindustri, formed by 4 lands (Planeptune, Lastation, Leanbox and Lowee) and each have a goddess who rules over them (Purple Heart, Black Heart, Green Heart and White Heart). Now the story starts with all 4 goddesses battling each other in a land called Celestia, which is above Gamindustri. All 4 with the exact same objective, which is to win and rule over all 4 lands. After battling for a while, Black, Green and White heart consider getting rid of one of them to make the battle easier and join forces to get rid of Purple Heart. They successfully do it, Purple Heart falls off of Celestia, landing on Planeptune and losing her memory. After falling, a girl aspiring to be a nurse called Compa finds her and becomes friends with her, promising to help her getting her memory back.I find the gameplay good. It's easy to move around when free roaming and I found the controls for combat easy to get comfortable with. Besides, the combat's pretty varied, as each character has a lot of different attacks and special moves. Though playing this game can be a little difficult, depending on your situation. The game does support keyboard, but I highly recommend a controller.For a game that originally came out in 2011 for the PS3 and was ported to Steam and PSVita in 2014, I don't see much of a difference in graphics. Which doesn't mean it's bad, actually. If the game still lags for you, it's most likely because the game's loading too any enemies and any small details, in the dungeons.The game's pretty fun and if you pay attention, you can notice a lot of jokes. And also something which is pretty well made in this game, which is 4th wall breaking. A lot of it!But with all these pros, obviously the game also comes with it's share of cons. And I've experienced some of them. Even though this game is great, you may kinda get a little tired of some of the dungeons you'll see throughout the game, as Idea Factory recycled a lot of dungeon layouts and a lot of enemies, simply renaming them and making them stronger.  Two other examples I can give are that the game suffers from a glitch that can pretty much screw up your whole process if you don't save frequently. Sometimes in combat, the enemies will not move at all, during their turns. They'll just stare at your party without attacking at all. Idk the solution for this and a lot of people complain about the same issue in the Steam forums and so far, no solution to this problem. So if it happens, force close the game through the task manager. The last problem I can mention is that sometimes, the game randomly crashes in between intros. Idk if anyone else has had this issue, but it has happened to me a couple of times. But very rarely. So here's a piece of advice for you who buy the game: save frequently.This is something I'm gonna start doing, with my reviews. My final verdict for Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 1 is a 7/10.This is a great game. And it had potential to reach a higher score! Maybe even an 8/10, imo. But with the few issues it has and with so many recycled content in the game, it kinda drops the score I personally give the game. But still. It's a pretty fun experience and worth the money! I still strongly recommend this game to any JRPG fans and anyone who's looking for a new game to play.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I bought this game because of all the positive reviews and stupid (in a good way) looking setting.If the half naked anime girls don't turn you off (or, even better, you like this stlye) you can find a pretty solid game underneath. The story doesn't win an Oscar but is keeping me engaged. Most of the fun comes from the cute dialogues and references to anything game related anyway. The charakters break the fouth wall quite often and the overall atmosphere is very light-hearted. The game just wants to be fun and make you smile and succeeds.There are tons of items to find, buy and craft. Add a good variety of abilities, spells, combos, some kind synergies between characters (if they like each other, you get bonuses) and you get great possibilities to customize your party. If you like experimenting, the game might be for you. Getting all the Plans, trying things out can be pretty addictive.The combat is turn-based on a 2D-Battlefield. Positioning is key, since all attacks have an area of effect. Standing at a wrong place can seriously ruin your day. Attack animations are also pretty good, so cambat is challenging and fun to watch. I strongly recommend a gamepad for the best experience. Playing with keyboard and mouse is possible but doesn't feel great.I won't comment much on the graphics. Look at Screenshots and videos and decide for yourself. It's a bit outdated but not ugly. Works for me.However, this game is not without flaws.The combat can get repetetive after a while, since the game tends to be quite grindy. You often have to get a few levels because of a difficulty spike and the MMO'ish quests (Kill X of these, bring me Y of that) increase this.The fact that dungeons and enemies are frequently recolored and reused does't make it better either. Oh, and you have to save often. There is no autosave and when you're dead, it's game over.To sum it all up: 7/10, fun game with some flaws. Would buy again

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												This is my first time ever approaching a Hyperdimention Neptunia game and to be honest, I had no idea what I was in for. I thought it would be a "OMG LOOK AT THE BOOBS JIGGLE" game. And let me tell you that while some jokes revolve around boobs and fanservice, that is not the main focus. Not by a long shot. I also played with a controller exclusively so I have no opinion on keyboard controlsThis is a wonderful JRPG adventure with well written, funny characters. The main character, Neptune jokes around quite a bit but knows when to be serious. It feels like an Anime that you play, in more ways than one. The combat is turn based but the attacks are flashy and pretty sweet to look at. Getting tired of basic attacks? You can unleash a powerful flurry of attacks using SP (mana/magic) or your EXE charges (built up from using any other action in battle). And as you level up, more basic attacks can be unlocked and substituted for your current attack combo.The story is quite intricate and complex, yet it takes it's time and makes sure you understand what's going on. The tale is mostly told in text boxes accompanied by lightly animated 2D characters. And by lightly, I mean they react to what's being said when dialogue is rolling and they sway gently when nothing is being said, so they they all feel alive. And the story is filled with plot twists and at any moment, a joke could pop out of nowhere, or the characters would break the fourth wall  addressing the scene or another character's behavior.Enemies all drop something upon death that is unique to that specific enemy, and the bestiary keeps track of which enemy drops what and what zone they could be found in. These materials are used to unlock items in the shop and complete plans. Plans do everything from modifying the game mechanics as a whole, modifying the items harvested in each zone and unlocking new items in the shop.The next few items are nitpicks because this game is a port from the PS Vita from what I understand. So i know that there may be a lack of memory left over for these details. and I'm willing to look past theseEnemy variety is new and fresh and the variety is wide. Some enemies will be the same in both model and texture exactly and the only difference visually will be the names. This trend isn't all that noticeable until you look at the bestiary. Certain enemies have a specific element attached. I found no use for the elemental attacks because it never seemed that I recieved a benefit from them at all. I know there was probably a system in place to address that but I just wasn't interested enough to care, since there was no internal way to know what attacks would be effective for each enemy (like final fantasy's Libra). Or maybe I just didn't understand the enemy's design hinted at the weakness, and I'm at fault here.Dungeons, stages, levels share motives and share styles. You won't notice it at first but as you progress through the game, levels will repeat shape and style with very slight changes and a new set of creatures. but they are mixed up enough that a return to a familiar layout isn't that bad.The problem with both of these nitpicks is when you return to an area to collect materials from an enemy, some of them look exactly the same. All run down factories share the same "Bit" design and skin. So the besiary keeps track of what you need.All in all, it is a fun freakin game and I highly recommend it to any fan of anime and JRPGs. 8 out of 10

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Update: After 51 hours (Excluding hours I left the game running and didn't play,) got all the Achievements for the Game. I enjoyed this game so much that it's literally the only game I actually bothered to do Achievements for. Also the first Game I actually decided to do the Trading Cards for. This is definitely a great casual Game worthy of many playthroughs.Really surprised with this title so far (14 hours into the Game at the time of this post.)The Story is quite... Interesting. It is not your typical straightforward story. The Basic plot is that the CPUs are in the middle of a Console War. Yes, a Console War. This is where your Story starts off. If you can comprehend that and the fact that the game has a lot of 4th wall breaking context to some times insult its players and have wacky dialogue, the Story is for the most part Satirical all the way through, which is very interesting, and I actually like it.One main piece of advice I can offer to any one interested in Re;Birth 1: I recommend one of two things.1. Watch the Anime. (The Anime is an adaptation of the Game, and takes place some time after the other games. Main reason I list this is because it's a good way to get used to the Characters, and if you can handle the wacky / cheesy dialogue in the Anime, you'll fit right in for the Game.)2. Grind. Grind. Grind, and buy Item Upgrades / make the Upgrades VIA Plans at every opportunity they become available.People say that this Game is pretty easy. Maybe if you played it before it came to Steam, that is understandable, but this Game is by no means easy. It is actually VERY hard / some times frustrating.The Game runs Eight Chapters. If you are not grinding / purchasing upgrades at every opportunity, you will notice how hard this Game can be when you get halfway through the 2nd Chapter. The other problem is that the Bosses have a lot of RNG to them, where they can either do a Normal hit to you, a Powerful hit that might kill you, or an Attack that hits all of your Party Members in close range, even if they aren't even in front of the Boss. Reviving your Party Members when they get downed is also RNG, because from what i've experienced in my own Playthrough, the Boss likes to immediately attack and kill the person you revive almost 90% of the time before it switches to one of your other party members. If you're coming into this game thinking that you'll blow through it without using Healing items or Game Over'ing at all, you're in for a rude awakening. Get used to how the Dungeons look in the first two chapters of the Game, because you're going to be seeing them all the way until the End. I can't knock them on this because if you can tell already that the Game doesn't take itself seriously and that it mocks a lot of things, especially in the Gaming world, you could see this as them mocking Games that use the same Layouts constantly.Soundtrack is also pretty decent, but a lot of areas unfortunately use the same background music way too often. Can't knock this either for similar reasons that I listed for Dungeons.If you can get past all this, this is definitely a very fun game, albeit very challenging as well. Would definitely recommend to any one that likes JRPGs, and I look forward to the rest of the Series coming to Steam.

												Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1, I love this game. I haven't played any of the previous installments of this series, but I personally do not feel like I'm missing out on anything.Pros:Witty and comical humor! (Nep-Nep makes this game great)Fun and intersting combatThe game delivers what a jrpg is - grinding levels (I enjoy constant battles to increase my characters levels and power)The story is actually fun to followSkimpy anime girls (If you bought the game obviously you're interested in this aspect)So many outfits to choose from!Cons:Because of the constant need to grind, the game doesn't feel as large as it should. Your time spent is in the same dungeons over and over.Lack of in-depth character customization (I didn't really expect this game to have it, but it would have been nice to have just a little more variety.The game is fun and if you enjoy jrpg this title is right up your alley. I own the other Neptunia games on Steam as well now because of this game and I expect the series only gets better.

												A very cute anime-styled JRPG full of self-referential humor and the occasional handful of fan service.The game can certainly stand on it's own merits, with an interesting turn-based battle system and a difficulty curve that never feels unfairly hard or boringly easy.There are also oodles of side-dungeons, item crafting, and quests to keep you busy and entertained until the credits roll and beyond.If you're looking for a light-hearted JRPG and aren't put off by anime girls and fourth-wall poking (and sometimes demolishing) humor, this is definitely worth picking up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												I bought this game because of all the positive reviews and stupid (in a good way) looking setting.If the half naked anime girls don't turn you off (or, even better, you like this stlye) you can find a pretty solid game underneath. The story doesn't win an Oscar but is keeping me engaged. Most of the fun comes from the cute dialogues and references to anything game related anyway. The charakters break the fouth wall quite often and the overall atmosphere is very light-hearted. The game just wants to be fun and make you smile and succeeds.There are tons of items to find, buy and craft. Add a good variety of abilities, spells, combos, some kind synergies between characters (if they like each other, you get bonuses) and you get great possibilities to customize your party. If you like experimenting, the game might be for you. Getting all the Plans, trying things out can be pretty addictive.The combat is turn-based on a 2D-Battlefield. Positioning is key, since all attacks have an area of effect. Standing at a wrong place can seriously ruin your day. Attack animations are also pretty good, so cambat is challenging and fun to watch. I strongly recommend a gamepad for the best experience. Playing with keyboard and mouse is possible but doesn't feel great.I won't comment much on the graphics. Look at Screenshots and videos and decide for yourself. It's a bit outdated but not ugly. Works for me.However, this game is not without flaws.The combat can get repetetive after a while, since the game tends to be quite grindy. You often have to get a few levels because of a difficulty spike and the MMO'ish quests (Kill X of these, bring me Y of that) increase this.The fact that dungeons and enemies are frequently recolored and reused does't make it better either. Oh, and you have to save often. There is no autosave and when you're dead, it's game over.To sum it all up: 7/10, fun game with some flaws. Would buy again

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												Let me be perfectly clear. I have not played a Neptunia game prior to Re;birth and it's moments like this that I wish I had pulled my head out of the ground sooner.The first that got to me about this game was certain terminology such as the Console War, or CPUs. Which do not stand for Central Processor Unit, mind you. It stands for Console Patron Unit (CPU). The game's lead character Neptune falls from the sky after a brutal, yet thrilling, battle with other CPUs, Black Heart, White Heart and Green Heart and loses her memory. Accompanied by Compa, she sets out to recover her memory and rescue Histoire. Whom she refers to as Histy. This is essentially the rundown of the story.But how does it play? Rather well I must say. It's simplistic but requires a fairly strategic mind. As it is the case with many a JRPG you can't afford to just head first into everything. You need to be at least a specific level before can reliably take on bosses. Even then it's more than likely to be a challenge. If nothing else, I must congratulate the team at IF for putting together a game that's challenging and fun. But if you happen to be a casual gamer, the Remake System got you covered.The true charm of this game, however, is not the gameplay but its characters. They are all well-thought out and fleshed out very well. So much so that you can keep playing the game again and again only to expose yourself to the humorous spectacle that is Hyperdimension Neptunia.Overall, Re;Birth1 is game that's worth your money and more. It's got a ton of content just waiting for you to unlock them. 241 hours and still don't have everything.

												There are three types of people who will enjoy this:People who like typical anime humour and archetypesPeople who like JRPGs and the abovePeople who like JRPGs but can ignore the aboveInside this game is a well thought out JRPG with lots of unique functions and ways to tackle enemies, while still remaining similar to the JRPG vein. The story thus far (I haven't completely finished the game yet) Is engaging enough to want to continue (At least it gets taht way for me past chapter 2), the combat is challenging and the boss battles really seem like boss battles.I'd recommend this to anyone who is both fans of JRPGs, love their waifus or can ignore some of the more niche comedy for a rich RPG experience.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												This is a remake of a PS3 JRPG that's also available on Vita. I hear the original was a much worse game, and I really don't dare imagine how that was like. It's a cheap budget JRPG (new price was 15 bucks on launch sale) with emphasize on cheap. There are only like half a dozen dungeon layouts, while there are 50 dungeons in the game. So basically each dungeon is copy pasted 10 times with only the enemies replaced. The dungeons are super short too, you can run from the entrance to the end usually in less than 5 minutes. The storyline is also only presented visual novel style with textboxes and talking heads. Cities are implemented as simple menus. So you either watch dialogues or you pick a dungeon from a list and run through it. Really this game probably cost less to make than the PS3 licensing fees...Still, it is suprisingly fun. Combat is turn based with a bunch of systems piled on it, and there is a massive crafting component involving hunting monsters for materials and crafting plans to unlock new equipment or dungeons. And the grind is so extremely streamlined, you can breeze even through special bosses within 10 seconds by liberal use of the ultra smooth animation cancel button. There are also absolutely no loading times, everything appears and works instantly. So the grind can downright turn into a rush and feels very satisfying. Think the loot and kill vortex of Diablo, but as a JRPG. Oh also the story is a parody of the console war in the current game industry. The entire cast of the game is female with permanent fan service forced in your face. The main character is a personified Dreamcast and there are also Playstation, Xbox and the Wii present. Ofc the Xbox has the biggest♥♥♥♥♥♥while the Wii is as flat as a washboard and gets extremely jealous if that's pointed out to her. At the start they are all mortal enemies but of course they eventually band together to fight a greater evil. It is in no way shape or form serious and constantly goofy and 4th wall breaking. I thought I would hate it but honestly, I think I prefer this absolute nonsense over yet another embarassing teenage melodrama or boring as ♥♥♥♥ Hero Alex gathers the stones of power to save the world from the evil wizard♥♥♥♥♥♥as you'd usually find in JRPGs.Mild recommendation.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												I really liked this game. The thing that killed it for me, hence only 15 hours or whatever played rather than the 70+ the top reviews have, was the massive grind to beat the second boss. Like, i had to grind for a very, very long time to beat that ♥♥♥♥ing boss. It was awful, boring and killed it for me.The combat in this game was pretty awful at first, but after tinkering around and figuring it out, it became a thing of beauty. After a little testing on your own, you'll be able to figure out which moves to use when and how to hit multiple enemies at once. It begins to feel like a little bit of strategy is needed to actually fight, which is nice.The sheer amount of content in this game is amazing also. There's so many things to craft and so many characters to level up (and dress up in some cases) that the 80 or so hours of playtime i see most people with is not surprising in the least. However, it can feel a little overwhelming if you're a perfectionist who actually wants to get close to a perfect runthrough.Another thing that should be mentioned is the tutorials aren't that great. They don't really explain enough, I feel, and you kind of have to figure it out on your own. That was also another "killer" for me because I spent probably an hour or two just messing around looking through all the different menus to figure out anything mildly helpful. I still honestly don't understand the point of some things or where to find certain items or how to check if an item is good before i spend hours grinding for monsters to drop the one thing i need...Anyway, most of my problems with the game could probably be easily avoided if you're up for googling and looking for guides before you get in depth. Also, being prepared for the huge grind needed to beat the second boss is a nice heads up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Just from 1 hour of gameplay, I can honestly say that buying this game was a terriffic choice! The game is exactly as advertised, a JRPG that takes various tropes and punches them in the face! The story is fairly good too. Otakus would probably understand what I mean when I say the game is like Hetalia but for the Video Game industry. The game's four main characters are all based on the 4 major gaming console manufacturers: Sega (Sega Neptune), Sony (Playstation), Nintendo (Wii), and Microsoft (XBox), and are in the midst of waging a war literally called "The Console War" in the world of "Gameindustri." Yeah, that's how this game rolls and thats just the beginning.This being a JRPG, the game has an opening like a traditonal anime and the opening is very good too. Be warned, the majority if not the entirety of the main cast are female and most appear to be the typical teenaged anime characters and there is some noticable "jiggle physics" on some of the characters. Just a fair heads up.Gameplay wise, keyboard controls are a bit dodgy. The game is meant to be played with a controller (which actually makes more sense considering the premice of the game itself) but has rebindable keys for keyboard. I recommend using an XBox 360 Controller (wired) as a fast alternative workaround.In terms of combat, the game is turn based but with an interesting twist. You can move the characters around within a certain radius, putting their target into a blue targeting box in front of them. You can target multiple enemies this way especially if they're clustered together. The enemy won't move until it's their turn too. One thing mouse and keyboard has an advantage over controler is that you can more carefully turn your characters so you can line up accurate attacks.

I still honestly don't understand the point of some things or where to find certain items or how to check if an item is good before i spend hours grinding for monsters to drop the one thing i need...Anyway, most of my problems with the game could probably be easily avoided if you're up for googling and looking for guides before you get in depth. Also, being prepared for the huge grind needed to beat the second boss is a nice heads up.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Hyperdimension is an interesting concept but not one that i thought id like, i watched the anime around a month before getting it and well i wasnt impressed, it was ok with a few laughs but didnt seem too great. Anyways i dont remember why but this game somehow got brought at some point and well i ignored it for a while then ran out of stuff to do so i was forced. Now at first i thought it was like the anime trying to be overcutesy but seriously this is gold.This game is in all seriousess a love letter to the art that is gaming.pros:-The game is long, main campaign takes around 25-30 hours id say, if you want the true ending then that adds a few more hours on and you will want to see it.-combat system is highly addictive and satisfying, its simple turn based mixed with hack and slash, a perfect mix of both worlds id say, struggle to think of a way they could improve it apart from adding more attacks or skills at high levels.-The storyline is some of the most hilarious stuff that you could ever come across-Animations and effects are extremely well done-Very good port, no drops, no crashes. its capped at 1080p but modding tools are at hand to change that minor flaw-Voice acting is some of the best, they really go with their various personalities, id go as far to say that its some of the best work ever done. Its in english or japanese, pick your poison.-Each charecters has their own skill set with 90% unique abilties, mostly the low level stuff is given to multiple charecters but they all have various weapon types so how those attacks come out will vary.-In depth lore based around consoles(mostly the older generation). Its a good send off to those consoles that have passed.Cons-People that havent played it will judge you(this bothers some people)- dungeons cant complex pretty linear- graphics dont blow your face off- Once finishing the game you will 100% of the time wonder what you are going to do with the rest off your life.(unless you have the sequel)All in all though, i cant recommend this enough, wheather you like anime or old games or funny stuff or lolis or consoles or lore maybe even general jrpgs this game is one of a kind. It gets overlooked a lot due to the fact that the way it presents itself isnt really the best style to go with in all honesty but when you look past it then its certainly in the top tier of games on the market.side note: use a controller(keyboard is fine but there is hassle)

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
Story/Presentation: 7I decided to try out this game in the Japanese language with English subtitles, of course, and I'm really glad I did. A lot of the English voice acting was very odd for me to hear and almost unbearable. I don't know what it is that some english dubbing is just so.. off putting. A lot of the lip-sinc was really off as well, so I forced myself to restart the game and try it out in Japanese. It somehow feels a lot more alive, more expressive, and you feel and know who the characters really are. So if anything, I would highly recommend going through the story and game in Japanese. Just pretend like you're watching a foreign film. As for the story, it's super cheesy, yet pretty enjoyable. I sort of saw it like a way to make fun of recent animes and make their own puns and the like. There is quite a bit of fan service here and there, but not the point where it's rubbed on your face, unless you like seeing underskirts during gameplay, but that can always be avoided. The art of the game, however, is very pretty to watch. The colors are very nice, and the art during the conversation sections are super pretty and pretty up to date compared to most games with this style. One thing I've noticed in game was when I just walk around a dungeun, I can somehow see the face normals on a model, and it just put me off a bit. It could of been because of the 'cyber world' gimick, but then it would of at least made it more obvious.Gameplay: 9Easily one of the best JRPGs I've played in a long time. I'm sort of selective when it comes to RPGs, specially turn-based ones, and this one works out just nicely! There's still a lot of movement involved, the challange is really big specially reaching Chapter 2, and it's just a lot of fun overall! As I mentioned, the Japanese acting works well with a lot of scenarios as well in game. The 'Plan' was an amazing feature in game, which I heard was what helped made the game better from it's original, and it was a good way to add in some sort of 'mods' to add weapons, make the game easier or harder, and to help with the fighting involving adding EXE power ups or even adding higher chances for enemies to drop items/resources. Everything works just fine, the only thing I wish was that there were more than just 3 characters to use in game, and that there were more moves to use, since a lot were just capped at Lv 3 EXE powers and the like. But even then, the New Game + is incredible, because even if you finished the game and start a new one with the same file, all of your character levels, all your items and equipments, all the plans, and even the MB Memories from Plans get transfered over. So when you start off from the first dungeon, you're already incredibly strong from the level you left off. Also, there is a lot of grinding involved.Overall: 9The game's incredibly cute and sexy, and also very fun to play. It can be addicting because of how easy you can level up and get so many items in game and the like. The characters are charming and loving in their own way, and I am personally excited for the second and third one to come out eventually on Steam. I highly recommend this game for Anybody into JRPGs and anime games in general!

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												tl;dr 10/10, lots of grinding with cute girls who are all waifu material, lots of fourth-wall breaking and endless references to things you like.A friend got me this game while it was on sale. Bless him. The game is basically a remake of an old game, but with much differences in the mechanics and story, apparently. I only read the wiki page, bare with me. Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 is set in a world called Gamindustri, which is made up of 4 countries: Planeptune, Lastation, Leanbox, and Lowee. A Goddess rules over each country, called the Control Patron Units, aka CPUs. The CPUs are constantly fighting each other to gain total control of Gamindustri. The game begins when the CPU of Planeptune got rekt by the other three and lost her memory, giving birth to our amnesiac protagonist.Thus starts the plot of the game. The game doesn't take its plot seriously, but that makes it fun. Pros:-Unique combo mechanic -Flashy attacks-Smooth animations-All the girls are waifu material -Characters are good-Story is not that original, but enjoyable nonethelessCons:-Needs a lot of grinding, but not the grinding I was hoping for -Repetitive level designs -If you buy this game you are a weeabooSo, why would you not buy this game? I demand you to get your wallet and toss your money at the screen this instant.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												The weeb in me loves this game. The RPG lover in me is left wanting more. The actual gameplay amounts to, breaking the enemy's guard, and then use your strongest attack until the enemy is dead. If you are not on the same level as the thing you are fighting, you're dead. And you'll need to grind. There are plenty of enemies that give a lot of experience so once you find those enemies you can get a lot of experience quickly. The actual gameplay of this game is not that fleshed out. You can move around and position your characters before you attack but the game does nothing to make you change where your characters are standing. An enemy MIGHT walk out of range from your party members and you MIGHT have to move them over an inch to attack them again. But there are no enemies that force you to move out of the way of a devastating attack. There are no enviromental hazards that force you to plan your movements during fights. Nothing like that. So being able to move your characters in fights is basically pointless. There's no real nudity in the game but there is a lot of cleavage and mention of breast sizes so it does well to titlate and make you laugh. But it doesn't do enough to challenge you in fights outside of: Are you high enough level? Ok you win. In conclusion, the fanservice is good, the gameplay is not. That being said. I can't really NOT recommend this game. I didn't get exactly what I wanted out of it. But that's not to say that you won't.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												Put Star Ocean, Final Fantasy and Phantasy Star Portable together with crazy cute flavouring and you probably have Hyperdimension Neptunia Re:Birth1.Hyperdimension Neptunia Re:Birth1 is an all-girl casted (spare a few NPCs) turn based RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously, with easy to learn but hard to master combat system. Felistella has taken the best of Hyperdimension Neptunia, Hyperdimension Neptunia mk2 and Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory, ripped apart the first of the three and rebuilt it, bringing us the definitive Hyperdimension Neptunia experience. The story is presented using 3D animations in the visual novel style, has decent pacing and the humour has quite a few laughs (but some groans, too). You'll move the story along primarily through dungeons and events activated in one of the game's four cities. Dungeons are explored in 3D third person, with treasure to find, resources to harvest and of course, lots of monsters to fight. While exploring a dungeon, monsters are encounted by making contact with them. You can get a pre-emptive attack on these monsters by performing a Symbol Attack, in which you swing your weapon at their hit box in the dungeon to initiate a battle. Should you fail to do so, monsters have a chance to launch a Surprise Attack. Otherwise who gets the first move is determined by the characters' agility stat vs the monsters'. Once defeated, monsters respawn after about a minute for you to fight again if you so desire, though they are easy to avoid should you not as they have relatively short leashes. One thing to note about the combat is that it has some really steep difficulty spikes. All monsters are not created equal, and while the last fight may have gone smooth as butter, the next one may be tough as nails. Certain monsters can become infected with a virus that will recover all damage they have sustained, and provide healthy boost to their stats. A single viral monster can potentially wipe out your party without either careful planning, or a quick escape! The toughest monsters in each dungeon, fortunately will not actively chase you if you don't want to fight them. Seemingly sure of their superiority and unconcerned with your insignificance, 'Risky Monsters' will ignore your existence unless you actively engage them.Outside of the combat system, the game has fully fleshed out shops with new weapons and armour regularly added. But besides that, the player has the ability to add items to the store through the Remake system. The Remake system is this game's version of crafting, which, as you'd expect allows you to craft items of all varieties including, but not limited to consumables, weapons, armour and costumes. But you can also use the Remake system to, with the right materials, alter the game's difficulty (easier or harder), manipulate which items drop in which dungeons, or even create new dungeons and quests altogether, should you have obtained the required Plan(s) to do so. Some of the harder side dungeons, which are difficult well beyond that of the story dungeons as well as the DLC Colusseum, can add quite a bit of longevity to a playthrough, and into New Game+.At its end, as far as JRPG PC ports go, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 sets the standard. After a little buggy release, the game runs smoothly on PC hardware new and old, supporting a wide variety of resolutions up to 1080p (but not 1200p for my monitor, the dastards!). However, it has a fixed graphics quality setting that looks okay but is about par for the course with what a PS3 or VITA would be capable of. My solitary complaint about the port is that the game does not seem to run in true fullscreen. My screen still goes into sleep mode while the game is running if I have walked away for a few minutes. This might seem like an upside to some, but for me it's a minor annoyance. 8.5/10

The updated gameplay is much more fun (no more gathering four items that magically become all healing and cure items).  There is no $10000 worth of DLC (there are 9 DLC items I believe, a few of which are free).

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												There’s a kind of poetic irony in remaking a game designed to poke fun at the game industry, considering all the remakes and reboots already flooding shelves. To both its credit and detriment, Re;Birth1 carries that identity struggle throughout. Sometimes the in-jokes and references are spot on, while others fail to critique and instead repeat old mistakes. What could have been a new start for the series instead becomes a merely average role-playing game that just doesn’t fit together completely. It’s lighthearted, and sports some fun, giant-anime-weapon battles, but its lack of challenge causes it to grow stale quickly.The best part of the Hyperdimension Neptunia games is inarguably the concept: Four goddesses, each representing a different game system, are waging a “Console War” against one another in a cutesy, high-octane anime fashion. Following this idea, Re;Birth1 is filled with meta, fourth wall-breaking humor, and a good bit of charming self-awareness. Pretty much every character and party member you encounter along the way fits into some sort of anime or gaming archetype — Neptune, who represents the fourth (imaginary) console, is the high-energy, childlike protagonist, while Iffy is a smart tsundere who can get quite flustered at times — and Re;Birth1 actually does a good job of balancing character versus caricature. That's about where "good balance" ends, however.One cheeky addition along the same self-aware vein is the “remake” system, which changes aspects of dungeons like enemy difficulty and the types of items that appear. It’s good in theory , but in practice, it’s not all that fun to go through old dungeons again just to get new items. I didn’t think grinding was at all necessary, either, so “remaking” a dungeon to increase the challenge didn’t make a whole lot of sense.Grinding is made unnecessary, by the way, due to the relative ease of combat. It’s of the basic turn-based, open-movement variety, and I found it functional, yet underwhelming. The only strategy I really needed was to have my healer heal between attacks and kind of brute force my way through things, though a few harder fights were more satisfying. A partnering system that allows one party member to loan her battle perks to another while staying out of harm’s way adds another dimension to battle, but it’s not really necessary, and ultimately, it just made battles easier, not more exciting.The story and dialogue both suffer from the same identity problems that permeate every other aspect of Re;Birth1, being simultaneously irritating and endearing at times. If a monster was clearly too hard for the area, I realized it before the characters sassily pointed it out, and I don’t need a dozen mentions of the word “tsundere” to realize which characters fit the archetype. Again, the ideas were there, but they were either too shallow or too frequent, rendering them moot. But I also found it adorable and loved playing as a group of dorky girls, at least for a while.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Definitelly an amazing game. Took me hours to complete it, but I loved every bit of it. It's half a rpg and half a visual novel. It kinda lacks in viarity in creature and section designs, but definitelly doesn't lack in character hat and dress types. And boobs. Cannot forget the boobs.The game is funny and has funny characters all around. And it even makes fun of the average tropes and cliches of JRPGs, which I find very amusing. There's sexual innuendos as well, but they are rather lighthearted ones. Which I didn't mind later on into the game. The story is kinda lacking in my opinion, though. There could be so much more.Gameplay is fun. It's turn based where you can move around in a area, but it has very little strategy. You just try and smash the enemy as much and as quickly as you can until it drops dead. To add more, there are various sections which can be used to power level really fast. So the story quests should go rather easy if you find out the mosnters that give pleanty of exp and are rather easy to kill with HDD'd ladies (spoiler: yeah, the universe revolves all around technology, specifically computer and computer games. So there's a lot of 4th wall breaking). If you bought all of the dlc, getting to level 999 is quite a trip. Even then though, you can just power level in a few hours of hardcore grinding.Honestly, the game is mostly all story, character design and hats, hats and more hats for ladies and their HDD's. Gameplay is fun if you like turn based, brainless smashing and big numbers, lots of grinding, and badges/collectables. I'm not complaining, as I kinda like that. But you should think twice if you dislike any of these things I mentioned, because the game's quite expensive. I'd suggest buying it at a discount unless you are a hardcore fan of the series or you imagine yourself loving the game/series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												After playing this game for over 100 hours, I can definitely say without a doubt that this game is worth trying out.  The story The story was very enjoyable to play through. It does not take itself seriously and that is what I love so much about it. It dives into a topic that all gamer can relate to, The Console War. It's both stupid and fun at the same time and the game capture that feeling almost perfectly with its hilarious story line and sometimes literally laugh out loud moment. Storywise, this is the strongest part of the game without a shadow of a doubt. The gameplay The game is a tactical strategy turn-based game where each character takes turn positioning themselves in the best way possible to deal out maximum power to as many enemies as possible. Dealing damages to enemies will fill up your "EXE gauge". After it is filled you are allowed to unleash some really powerful attack that will decimate your enemies in very stylistic ways. You can also create something called a "Game Disk" where you can burn multiple chips with various perks to help you in combat. It's very useful to get the hang of this system early on as it can help you from anywhere as increasing your EXP gained from battles to healing and replenishing your HP and SP. You can also mix and match different characters as each have their own passive abilities that will boost and help their teammates in battles. This is very important because not only are you gaining passive abilities but by putting certain characters together, you can unlock certain moves that are almost twice as powerful and effective. This leads to multiple ways to play the games. Gameplay wise, it is also solid. Graphic Graphically, this is the weakest part of the game. It was ported from the PS Vita and it really shows. The textures look terrible and there is very little customization that you can do in the game when it comes to the video setting. The details are bland and are very unsatisfying to look at. Not to mention this game reuses A LOT of enemies and dungeon making it worse as you are constantly looking at the same five or six design being stretch out to over thirty areas of the game. The enemies have very littles varieties from each others that are within their own species. It is very littles changes that just scream laziness. This is the one department that you need to really worry about and take into consideration when deciding to purchase this game. My final verdict It was very hard for me to write that last part because I really love this game. And anytime there is a big flaw that is in the game you love it just really suck. But, if you are willing to look over the graphics and the disappointing varieties of dungeons and enemies in the game I think you can honestly have a great time with this game. My recommendation is to buy the game on sale if you are still unsure. That is what I did. I bought it for $8.99 and I don't regret a single thing. I think this game warrants a chance to be play. Even if you don't like it, you can just refund it and get your money back. So, what are you waiting for? Give the game a chance!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												I originally tried Neptunia mk2 on the PS3, and wasn't that crazy about it. In addition to the wildly fluctuating fps, the battle system didn't really click with me, and I wasn't interested in the story enough to continue. I have to say though, this remake of the first game that apparently takes from Victory's battle system has just the tweaks it needed to be really enjoyable. Plus, being able to play the game in 60fps is beautiful, and the port in general while rocky at the start, is great compared to the track record of others. Beautiful artstyle, self-aware jokes, flashy attacks, fanservice, and enough grinding to satisfy that Disgaea itch, is a recipe for a relaxing experience.

												BOING BOING BOING.. come on, JUST PAUSE and look at all that Dogoo bouncing!(that blue ball of slime lovingness) On a serious note,Anime fans or pervs around the world, this is the cherry to your cake or make that the game which will take away your cherry... For a game ported from the handheld consoles to the pc, it is already holding up well to the control mechanics(still clumsy around the controls but you will get it sooner, or perhaps 10 years down the road when you're still playing this game)Story? well you're going about getting a whole crew of waifus to defeat a villain while going through dungeons after dungeons in order to get more materials.. kinda your typical RPG game, BUT with the option of being able to take any chracter and dressing them up for battle.. and being so god darn cute.. ITS A WINNER IN MY BOOKS!!!!:PThis game gets some serious rev in its difficulty past chapter 2-3 which just means more grinding, initially you may think this game is just a waste of time pressing and it should just recieve them pictures of Dogoos but you're hella wrong, gamers can't live without a little challenge now can they?!(unless you're a bondfide pervert and kudos to you...)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												First of all, beware of that I am not very good at englishat last , I finish my first round on this game so I start to  reviewStory line is kinda "ok". It's not superb or anything like that. very linear story line and have only 2 type ending, Soft story  and make joke of console war and some refer to japanese animation.If u get the joke then u will have more fun. that mean u need to be in this kind thing for long enough.although, I only got some joke.transalation is off a bit. It's  not wrong but may be translate by person who is not into japanese anime-game.killing off some joke.Charater desigen and Art is very good. not in term of realistic but they can moe-lization anything. Voice actress is good too ,this can make u more in love with charater.(Btw , I only listen in japanese)anyway, it's up to player preferences. but there are  many type of character for u to fall in love(wait!?, this not dating-sim or Visual Novel) Don't expect Superb quality 3D graphic from this game . it's now 1080p  but lack option to adjust graphic . And texture on object not much high resolution anyway. and recycling mob design a lot of time.Gameplay like J-rpg style . Main story ,side quest , some thing  like crafting but call "Plan"  that can do more than crafting item , give u a lot of side track to do before main story . Oh , and Coliseum fight. Actually, Plan and Coliseum fight are more challenging than main story. A bit of dressing game element on Plan . u can make wearable thing for your charater to look cuter , cooler or anything u want.  but a lot of these content u need to buy from dlc first to unlock and to do plan to get it later.this game is Replayable game. if u want to do many plan thing or if like to get all non-dlc character then u wolud like to play another round. (get all non-dlc character in one round is possible but u will miss to do many other Plan thingand if u need to get both ending U need to play one more round anyway)Coliseum Fight and Do plan that kinda grinding take a lot of time. it's up to player preferences again.if u like grinding it's fun. if not, just finish 1 or  May be 2round  so u can get both ending and then go play other game.I have some porting bug. right joystick is not working but  there have manual way to fix this in community guide.other issue I got temporary freezing(on AMD graphic card)or Black out(on Nvidia card)though, still  playable.overall , it's good . not as just moe-moe game but gameplay is good too. but far different philosophy from western RPG.if u like J-rpg and Moe-moe thing, u  likely to like it.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												I'm Actually On A Midpoint On This Game, But Since I Pretty Much Like This Game, I'll Give A Thumbs Up.Pros:-Anime(If You Like It!)-Cliches EVERYWHERE. It's Great. (Assuming You Like Cliches)-Tropes(?)-Kawaii Anime Grils That Have A Secondary Form-People Who Like This Will Most Likely Start To Want The Rest Of The Games, Unfortunatly For PC Gamers, Only The Remakes Are Coming To PC. The Remakes Are Probably Better Though.-(DISCLAIMER: I HAVE NOT PLAYED THE ORIGINALS.) Probably More Laid Back Story Than The Predecessors. (AGAIN. DISCLAIMER: I HAVE NOT PLAYED THE ORIGINALS.)-Implied Yuri(Go Search It Up If You Don't Know.)-Always That One Gamer Perv, Tsundere(Search It Up.), Quiet One That Explodes(Metaphoriclly) When Angered, And Fourth-Wall Breaker.-One Hell Of An Achivement Hunt.(At The Time Of Making This Review, I Have 3 Achievements To Get. Two Of Which Are Pretty Hard Achievements.)Con:-Controls Are A Bit Wonky, But When You Get Them All Sorted Out, They're Perfectly Fine. Also, This Game Is A PS Game, So I Think It's In Your Best Interest To Get The Steam Controler Or A PC PS Controler. I Didn't Have One.-Too Many References That The Game Could Suffice Without.-Ecchi(? Depending If You're Ok With It.)-Lots Of DLC, More Money Needed.-No Playable Male Character. AT ALL. (Common Cliche For A Male To Have His Harem Of Girls, All Of Which Are In Love With Him.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												If you know what Neptunia is you don't need to read much of thisContrary to other recommendations hereThere are no realtime physics in this game despite what you might expectContent could be longer; story is shorter than I expected.Combat is a novel mix, reminds me of both turn-based like FF-X and strategic-realtime action like FF-XIIIGraphics could have been enhanced more - it still looks like it came off the PS Vita (which it did.)Music is a mixed bag. There are some individually nice tracks, some ear-worms, but as a whole the problem is a lack of coherency. It's mostly digitalized in nature as expected of the theme, but ... it just doesn't come together, especially if you go through the Audio Museum all at once. On another note some of the tracks have some really peculiar names.References: nep-nep/nowa-nowa

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												First off, I'd like to say that I watched the HDN anime first without even knowing what it was about. Eventually, I found out that its origins were from a game (a terrible one). I was a bit skeptical at first when I bought it, but it was 50% off so why not?Based on the many reviews I've read about the original game, I'm glad that I bought this one. The Remake System that is included in the HDN Re;Birth 1 has done wonders for the game and allowed for drastic improvements to be made overall.I don't want to get into any spoilers, but I will say that this is one of the best JRPG I've laid my hands on.  The artwork, plot, characters, music. EVERYTHING JUST FITS PERFECTLY. Maybe it's just me, but the BGM during boss fights and EXE drives gives me tingles every time I get into a battle.  The light-hearted personality of Neptune just makes everything 9999% better.  I've only just recently hit lvl 999 with Neptune alone and I'm planning on doing the rest.  This game is awesome. I haven't even slept yet and I don't even regret it.Nep-Nep 2 sugoi

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Little over 12 hours in and I have come can say with absolute certainty that this is one of the most weeb games i have every  played.Pros:BoobsFan serviceFunnyBouncy Boobs Interesting storyThe "plan" system can make the most innocent looking monster as hard as your weiner doodle while playing this. Can run amazing even on a low spec PCCons: Fan service (Im not complaining but when my family saw this they couldnt help but question me.) If you want to %100 clear this game then be prepared for the long haul. The dungons repeat, along with the enemies (switch the colors and buff the stats and VOLA new enemy!)Alot of reading (Dating Sim style, but they put a bunch of jokes in the reading to make it tolerable)The game is NOT worth $30, wait for it to go on sale. The Delux edition does not effect game play so unless you want the soundtrack, artbook, and walpapers for $10 dont buy. I bought this for about $17 with all the DLC, and recomend you get it since it comes with items and charcters that make early game stages alot easier to navigate and get through.  All in all I love the game

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Taking into account the scale of the game there is easiliy over 50+ hours worth of content in this game, very well made JRPG with quite a few comical references to other games.Pros:. Has an in depth character customization system, including a "Super form" which also gies you even further customization options.. 60 FPS ( Requirement for me nowadays ). good graphics.. Plenty of hours of gameplay, well worth the asking price.COns:. Mediocre story. Can get quite repetitive.Overall I would recommend this game. it's well worth the asking price of the game and has enough content to keep you engrossed for at least 20 hours if you focus only on story.

												After playing 94 hours on the game and feel quite "finished" with it, unlocking almost everything and getting up to lvl 999 and grabbed all legendary gears, i'll just say "wow".Story: Kind of generic, but i liked it, and i fell in love with some of the characters here.Graphics: Well, i think they were fine and up to a pretty OK standard, didn't find much to complain about really.Dungeons: You will notice in maybe 1-2 hours of game play of re-made maps, they are well made but i feel that it's kinda boring to meet slight alteration of the dungeons.VA: I only speak from experience of the Japanese voice actors, so i can't say anything for the English ones, but i've heard they have been good for being English voice actors.Characters: Yes, they are kind of generic personalities you find all over japanese anime/manga/games, but i didn't feel like they destroyed the enjoyment of the game.Music: Some songs here are epic and good, but i didn't find anyone being "bad".All in all i'd give it a 8/10, could have done a better job on the dungeons and story only being about 35 hours long (with grinding, seen speed runs as low as 1.5 hours long).But the experience and fun i've had was well worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												It's a very niche game made on a tight budget. Expect a lot of reused content (identical dungeons, palette swap enemies), and that everything happens in a VN way, mostly offscreen. If you like JRPGs, you might find the content a little bit too thin.With that in mind, I'd recommend the game just on this "something" it has that kept me playing. The characters are likeable and the dialogue humorous. The writing is very self-aware and has a lot of references, but it has charm, the references and 4th wall breaking moments are overt enough not to feel forced or heavy-handed. There's some fanservice, but it's not sleazy, just a scene of Neptune getting a bandage bikini early on and later some awkward hugs.The music is catchy, battle animations and 3d models are well-animated, there's a lot of different weapons and outfits to grind for, and the battle system is complex enough to be interesting throughout the whole game (there's a battle animation button skip under left bumper, which eases the pain of grinding a lot).Buy it if you'd like a laid-back story and just a bit of challenge. Don't if you don't like moeshit anime.Iffy a best.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												After playing this game for over 100 hours, I can definitely say without a doubt that this game is worth trying out.  The story The story was very enjoyable to play through. It does not take itself seriously and that is what I love so much about it. It dives into a topic that all gamer can relate to, The Console War. It's both stupid and fun at the same time and the game capture that feeling almost perfectly with its hilarious story line and sometimes literally laugh out loud moment. Storywise, this is the strongest part of the game without a shadow of a doubt. The gameplay The game is a tactical strategy turn-based game where each character takes turn positioning themselves in the best way possible to deal out maximum power to as many enemies as possible. Dealing damages to enemies will fill up your "EXE gauge". After it is filled you are allowed to unleash some really powerful attack that will decimate your enemies in very stylistic ways. You can also create something called a "Game Disk" where you can burn multiple chips with various perks to help you in combat. It's very useful to get the hang of this system early on as it can help you from anywhere as increasing your EXP gained from battles to healing and replenishing your HP and SP. You can also mix and match different characters as each have their own passive abilities that will boost and help their teammates in battles. This is very important because not only are you gaining passive abilities but by putting certain characters together, you can unlock certain moves that are almost twice as powerful and effective. This leads to multiple ways to play the games. Gameplay wise, it is also solid. Graphic Graphically, this is the weakest part of the game. It was ported from the PS Vita and it really shows. The textures look terrible and there is very little customization that you can do in the game when it comes to the video setting. The details are bland and are very unsatisfying to look at. Not to mention this game reuses A LOT of enemies and dungeon making it worse as you are constantly looking at the same five or six design being stretch out to over thirty areas of the game. The enemies have very littles varieties from each others that are within their own species. It is very littles changes that just scream laziness. This is the one department that you need to really worry about and take into consideration when deciding to purchase this game. My final verdict It was very hard for me to write that last part because I really love this game. And anytime there is a big flaw that is in the game you love it just really suck. But, if you are willing to look over the graphics and the disappointing varieties of dungeons and enemies in the game I think you can honestly have a great time with this game. My recommendation is to buy the game on sale if you are still unsure. That is what I did. I bought it for $8.99 and I don't regret a single thing. I think this game warrants a chance to be play. Even if you don't like it, you can just refund it and get your money back. So, what are you waiting for? Give the game a chance!

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Just finished this, and have to say it was a pleasant surprise. A really fun, cute, and lighthearted story, likable characters, and an okay combat system. The combat felt like the weakest part of the game I admit, and at times the game relies too much on level grinding and enemies with cheap attacks. In addition, I noticed the game was guilty of re-using dungeons, just with a new enemies. However, the story kept me playing, as I mentioned, a lot of silly, entertaining dialogue and a great tongue in cheek look at video games. Overall, very enjoyable, and it made me a fan of the series. Well reccomended for fans of moe or those looking for a light JRPG.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Before playing this game one must ask themself "Deep within do I want to be a cute little girl who can beat everything up and transform into a no longer cute but voluptuous woman who can rain destruction down onto even the most powerful of foes?" If your answer is anything but "yes" then stop reading. I heard a bit about Neptunia from a friend of mine, but I never gave the game much thought. After being released on steam and looking at the screenshots I knew I had to play it especially since it's a JRPG. In the end I thought this was a very fun game with a charming atmosphere, a good game to play to unwind.Pros: There's a fair bit of the game that has voice acting, and the acting isn't really bad (it's only really bad if you look at lipsynching in which case there really isnt any...dialogue trails away from the character's mouth movements)After getting used to them, the controls can be very intuitive.Cons:Button mapping, despite being a PC port of the game it still shows all the buttons of a playstation controller. This took me some getting used to but after rebinding a few keys here and there I was good to go.The in-between: Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1's level scale felt a bit strange to me. There are points in the game where you can be "underleveled" but take on enemies with great ease, and other times where you can be incredibly "overleveled" and still feel like you're making zero progress.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												I originally tried Neptunia mk2 on the PS3, and wasn't that crazy about it. In addition to the wildly fluctuating fps, the battle system didn't really click with me, and I wasn't interested in the story enough to continue. I have to say though, this remake of the first game that apparently takes from Victory's battle system has just the tweaks it needed to be really enjoyable. Plus, being able to play the game in 60fps is beautiful, and the port in general while rocky at the start, is great compared to the track record of others. Beautiful artstyle, self-aware jokes, flashy attacks, fanservice, and enough grinding to satisfy that Disgaea itch, is a recipe for a relaxing experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												One of the few RPG's with an all female cast (there are a few males, but none of them even have a proper sprite), and it is full of self aware humor and references. The game is also very easy to get into with a simple battle system, and item unlocking system. All and all, a fairly good game to just play and relax as you enjoy the humor along with a basic RPG.However, that isnt to say the game is without flaws. For one, the dungeons are too simplistic and short. They are more like small fields for the character to walk on. Some also feel empty and near pointless, like the snowfields. This isnt helped by the lack of variety of music between areas. You're inner dungeoneer will grow hungry.Of course, if you are looking for a serious RPG with an epic storyline and any serious moments what-so-ever, you are looking at the wrong game. This game is for those that want a good laugh while playing something easy.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												First of all, beware of that I am not very good at englishat last , I finish my first round on this game so I start to  reviewStory line is kinda "ok". It's not superb or anything like that. very linear story line and have only 2 type ending, Soft story  and make joke of console war and some refer to japanese animation.If u get the joke then u will have more fun. that mean u need to be in this kind thing for long enough.although, I only got some joke.transalation is off a bit. It's  not wrong but may be translate by person who is not into japanese anime-game.killing off some joke.Charater desigen and Art is very good. not in term of realistic but they can moe-lization anything. Voice actress is good too ,this can make u more in love with charater.(Btw , I only listen in japanese)anyway, it's up to player preferences. but there are  many type of character for u to fall in love(wait!?, this not dating-sim or Visual Novel) Don't expect Superb quality 3D graphic from this game . it's now 1080p  but lack option to adjust graphic . And texture on object not much high resolution anyway. and recycling mob design a lot of time.Gameplay like J-rpg style . Main story ,side quest , some thing  like crafting but call "Plan"  that can do more than crafting item , give u a lot of side track to do before main story . Oh , and Coliseum fight. Actually, Plan and Coliseum fight are more challenging than main story. A bit of dressing game element on Plan . u can make wearable thing for your charater to look cuter , cooler or anything u want.  but a lot of these content u need to buy from dlc first to unlock and to do plan to get it later.this game is Replayable game. if u want to do many plan thing or if like to get all non-dlc character then u wolud like to play another round. (get all non-dlc character in one round is possible but u will miss to do many other Plan thingand if u need to get both ending U need to play one more round anyway)Coliseum Fight and Do plan that kinda grinding take a lot of time. it's up to player preferences again.if u like grinding it's fun. if not, just finish 1 or  May be 2round  so u can get both ending and then go play other game.I have some porting bug. right joystick is not working but  there have manual way to fix this in community guide.other issue I got temporary freezing(on AMD graphic card)or Black out(on Nvidia card)though, still  playable.overall , it's good . not as just moe-moe game but gameplay is good too. but far different philosophy from western RPG.if u like J-rpg and Moe-moe thing, u  likely to like it.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Grindy. As in, hella grindy, but still fairly enjoyable.If this is your first nep game (as it was mine) you can easily pick it up from the start and not feel like you've missed anything story-wise. Gameplay is fairly simple even for someone new to turn-based RPGs. The humor of the game can feel beaten-in after a while, but all in all was still pretty good. As far as the content of the game, admittedly its a lot of copy and paste. Most of the dungeons and enemies are just reskins from earlier parts of the game. The characters are cute, and the animations for the EXE or SP moves can be interesting to watch the first few times. There's an offer of replayability thanks to some materials being limited to only be obtained once per playthrough, so if you wish to unlock everything in the game, you'll be playing through it multiple times.Its also worth noting, to those new to the series/JRPGs, Neptunia is basically a hybrid between an RPG and a Visual Novel. In my experience with the game, about 50% of my time was spent reading text (don't use the english dub, its awful), and the other 50% was wandering dungeons and killing mobs, until the second playthrough came and I was instead grinding mobs for specific materials.Even though the game has clear negative points, it must be doing something right to have kept me entertained for over 60 hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												One of my best favorite franchise in either game, anime, and manga, this game offer a good graphic JRPG Anime style. This is one of the most well-known franchise of Idea Factory that offer so many aspect and feature toward JRPG and Anime Lover. Hyperdimension Neptunia Rebirth 1 is the true beginning of the story line in the whole franchise (I strongly advise you to play this game first before to know the whole plot).Pros:- Astonishing cute character development- Dungeon design looks fabulous- Great Soundtrack- Fascinating DLC (Especially DLC Character MUST BUY!)- Light Atmosphere story (Very Relaxing)- Challenging Enemies and Side Quest- Offer 2 different endings- Character customization is very vary (From Weapon, Skill, Armor, Accessories, and Clothes)- Transformable character are present making a potent hero in a serious battle- 2 languages available (English and Japanese)- Has a secret character- So many playable character- Various combo mechanism- Featured a Lily Rank system (Boost up the power of "Paired Character")- Unlimited leveling capacity (Can up to Lv.300)- Visual Novel Animation is very good- Variety of CG gallery- Unique battle system (Turn Based Movement Battle)- Hilarious conversation- Various parody element presentsCons:- Skills in every character is quite few- Has no real Open World system, it is more dungeon oriented game (Quite different by other most JRPG games)- The dungeon offer no other elements, except enemy, treasure, save point and area exploration (Which very standard and not unique at all)- Skill development is decent (no unique at all)- Very level and equipment dependent, so if your level and your equipment is great enough you can easily defeat almost all enemies in the game and that is quite boring (not really strategic and challenging)Overall this game is a masterpiece for the beginning of it's franchise, I highly recommend this game for Anime lover, RPG fan, and visual novel lover. I actually loved this franchise so much, especially the beginning one. Keep up the good work Ideal Factory and please keep adding your Neptunia series (with new content is better) on Steam, I gladly support you! XD

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												It's a very niche game made on a tight budget. Expect a lot of reused content (identical dungeons, palette swap enemies), and that everything happens in a VN way, mostly offscreen. If you like JRPGs, you might find the content a little bit too thin.With that in mind, I'd recommend the game just on this "something" it has that kept me playing. The characters are likeable and the dialogue humorous. The writing is very self-aware and has a lot of references, but it has charm, the references and 4th wall breaking moments are overt enough not to feel forced or heavy-handed. There's some fanservice, but it's not sleazy, just a scene of Neptune getting a bandage bikini early on and later some awkward hugs.The music is catchy, battle animations and 3d models are well-animated, there's a lot of different weapons and outfits to grind for, and the battle system is complex enough to be interesting throughout the whole game (there's a battle animation button skip under left bumper, which eases the pain of grinding a lot).Buy it if you'd like a laid-back story and just a bit of challenge. Don't if you don't like moeshit anime.Iffy a best.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												A mere two hours into the game and it's already miles better than I'd expected it to be. Having played Hyperdimension Neptunia from its very first installment up to Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory on the PS3, I can say that having this game on PC is definitely a better experience even if just for the 60 FPS improvement alone.I'd never played anything from the "Re;Birth" line and I've been pleasantly surprised by how much of an improvement this remake of the first game is. It's not a simple remaster at all, it's literally a remake. Tasteful dialogue has been added to this game alongside the battle system from the later installments in the series, which makes it a genuinely fun game to go through instead of a headache-inducing experience. Speaking of headaches, if anyone here has played the first game on the PS3 then you'd know how much of a pain some of the soundtrack was to listen to. Even the soundtrack in this game has been composed completely differently and the pieces are pretty fun to listen to. High energy with catchy melodies and the mixes themselves are great. When it comes to choosing either the Japanese or English dub, it simply all comes down to personal preference. The only gripe I have with the English dub is that it doesn't have voice acting during quite a few scenes where the Japanese one does. If you're the type of person who doesn't care about the language or expression, and would just like to have a full audio experience with speech, then the Japanese option will give you that. Otherwise the English dub is still quite good. I myself am indecisive and keep switching between the two.The visuals are of course much better in the PC version due to the improved framerate, and although the game doesn't have an in-built 1080p resolution option, there is a work-around posted in the forums. If by any chance you are having issues with this game involving cutscenes being automatically skipped, you simply need to go and install CCCP or the "Combined Community Codec Pack". It'll fix a lot of issues you may have with other forms of media as well. Thankfully I've yet to come across a single bug in this game myself.It's been said by a fair few people, but it's true that a controller is optimal for playing this game. The in-game tutorials present you with buttons for a controller setup without giving you direct guidance for a mouse and keyboard, and even when you work it all out it's pretty unpleasant in its default state. Don't let that turn you off from this game if you're interested though, because you can just reassign everything obviously. Even still, go grab that controller to make it easy.All-in-all this is the best Hyperdimension Neptunia experience I've had yet in terms of visuals, audio and performance. If you're a fan of the anime aesthetic, light-hearted humour, cool combat and JRPGs in general, then you're going to have a blast with this game. I hope to see the support being given to the PC release cause more games like this one to come to PC.
