content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
Hyperdimension Neptunia; reBirth1 is a traditional Japanese role playing game combined with a visual novel. The game caters to a niche audience and makes no effort to accommodate newcomers or uninitiated. The storyline borders on the acceptable limits of both the narrative meta and the digital millennium copyright act. The gameplay is demandingly taxing on the player’s patience. Furthermore, the presentation is borderline insanity and will ultimately make or break the experience. Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 is a game that only pleases a very narrow audience through a collection of either off-putting or appealing elements. The game’s storyline demands an extreme measure of patience from the player and a great deal of tolerance for overused references and clichés. Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 is set in Gameindustria; an analogous universe that represents the four sided console war of the seventh generation. Each nation or faction is governed by a goddess, or avatar, that represents the faction’s home console. The player takes control of Neptune, an amnesiac avatar who represents Sega, who in turn has to travel the world and gather allies and fight enemies in the respective lands referencing Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo.Each nation is headed by a respective goddess with each their own distinct appearance and personality. The ensemble cast is rounded out by characters representing popular franchises and companies such as Tekken and Monster Hunter. The plot has Neptune search the lands for her purpose in life and reason behind the constant attacks on everyone’s nations by a mysterious adversary. The majority of the plot is told through scrolling text accompanied with expressive portraits. The sheer extent of time that is spent reading is jarring. A large portion of the narrative is dedicated to characters’ development, usually manifesting in a three-way discussion on the merits of substantial bosoms or the palatability of dairy products. The discussions are rife with references to videogame history, internet memes and porn chichés which all add up to a staggering number of times that the player will end up rolling their eyes and sighing in mild annoyance. The overall experience is not helped by the characters instance on breaking the fourth wall and actually berating themselves for talking too much, only to resume the cacophony of clichéd locution. In all, the plot wafer thin in depth, richly spread with stale tropes and references. Gameplay revolves around a battle system and exploration with some novel ideals, but ultimately grows stale and monotonous. When not trapped in an incessant lecture on the benefits of fruits from the nightshade family the game plays like a traditional Japanese role playing game. The player explores dungeons with different enemies and treasures to fulfil quests and craft new items. The crafting system allows the player not only to make new weapons and armour, but also reduce the difficulty to increase the amount of power generated when using attacks or the amount of experience points awarded after a fight.A general battle will be turn based, with each character being a given a slot in a sequential order governed by the character’s statistics. The player must the position the character adjacent to the enemy and select from the available attacks. Attacks come in three varieties and are either geared toward the generation of EXE power, dealing raw damage or the deterioration of the enemy’s defence gauge. When a certain amount of EXE power is earned additional attacks may be used or the special abilities may be unleashed to generally annihilate the enemy in a grandiose and gratuitous manner befitting of a mainstream Japanese cartoon. While the system is fully customisable and offers some level of depth, it quickly degenerates into an automated sequence where EXE building will be followed by guard breaking and ultimately unleashing the aforementioned special attacks to quickly end the fight. However, while there is a system in place with elemental attacks and a physical versus magic attack split, it hardly ever has any effect on the battle’s procedure; eliminating any all need for proper tactics. Furthermore, the game’s difficulty tends to spike to unreasonable levels and demands a degree of mandatory grinding for experience before allowing the player to pass to the next chapter of the story. Naturally, grinding comes into play when using the craft system as it demands items only dropped by certain enemies. These enemies only drop the items by chance, so repetition sets in fast when the same enemy is slain over and over in an attempt to acquire a particular item. Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 stagnates fast under its almost archaically traditional combat system and barely acceptable random drop mechanics while exploring monotonous and linear dungeons. The overall presentation is where game finds its initial appeal, however, upon further inspection will be the most prominent factor for playing or dropping the game. While the game is bright and colourful, both in setting and characters, the game is terribly guilty of reusing its assets to a criminal extent. It is not uncommon to find the exact same enemy in the final stage as one you found in the introduction stage. Only the name will make any difference. The dungeons themselves fall victim to the recycling of assets as well. The game contains exactly one warehouse map, and it is reused five times, each time filled with the same or palette swapped enemies. The main characters themselves in the meantime suffer from stale animations. Characters seem to float over the ground rather than walking on it. Jumping might as well have been teleportation because it violates roughly eight of the twelve rules of animation. When attacking, there is either a blinding flurry with no weight to it, or a brutal swing that looked cool, but did not do any significant damage. During the story scenes the characters interact through portraits with various expressions. Particular focus is placed on character’s chest area. Considering the lack of assets in the aforementioned region on some of the characters in addition to the rather revealing attire, it might not be the best game to have installed on a hard drive if the player’s country of residence has a legal grey area in regards to the depiction of underage looking characters. The visuals are accompanied by music and voice acting that breach any and all limits that can be endured by a living soul. The music is catchy and appropriately a blend of techno, rock and chiptune. However, the cuts are extremely short, so the same few notes play ad infinitum until insanity ensues. The voice acting is beyond comprehension. Most characters have voices that are so high pitched they can shatter glass. The fact that most of the delivery consists of screaming and yelling only aggravates the situation. Considering that all the of game’s text is voiced will quickly lead to the realisation that in addition to a JRPG, this game also contains an audio book where the entire novel is screamed at you. Luckily the game features an English voice track that is considerable more subdued and less obnoxious in addition to not dubbing half the dialog in lieu of some much needed silence. In all, Hyperdimension Neptunia reBirth1 is a very special game with a number of features that appeal to a very small audience. However, for everyone else, this game suffers from stale gameplay, agonising voice acting, grating music, substandard animation and modelling, a bizarre story and dubious character development. Yet, if all of the aforementioned complaints are exactly the elements you are looking for in a game, then I would recommend it. Anyone else will want to take note of it, and rather look for a more conventional game.

content:
Posted: January 6
												One of the greatest JRPGs to ever be made. Seriously, up there with the Final Fantasy series. Possibly even better. The gameplay mechanics are deceptively complex and in-depth - easy to learn but difficult to master. The combat system seems to me like a mix between Final Fantasy X's Count Time Battle system and Fire Emblem's strategic movement system. Sounds weird, but I promise you, it all comes together. This is a PS Vita port, so a controller is almost necessary, but other than that, this runs like a charm and looks gorgeous. Oh, and also, Nep-Nep.10/10 would Nep-Nep again.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
When I bought this game I really didn't expect anything.I tend to have a habit of buying random cutesy anime games, even if they are decent at best. So I bought this, expecting to play it in spite of people... but I ended up really liking it.Like, really, really liking it. I expected this to be a decent (if even that) JRPG but after a few hours I was hooked with the ridiculously likable characters, non-sensical story, and simple-yet-interesting mechanics.---------------------------------------This being on PC, the PC port stuff comes first:It's not that good. It's not good at all really, but it does run at 60FPS, goes up to 1080p, and has borderless window as an option. No real graphics options. It's still quite obvious that it's a port of a Vita game, but the game still looks really nice, in my opinion. Do be aware that there are no button prompts in-game for keyboard controls. It always displays with Xbox buttons. I prefer playing the game with the 360 controller. If you play with the keyboard, note that if you can get past the fact that there are no help prompts, and that the controls are kind of awkward, the game is still very much playable.---------------------------------------Now, onto gameplay:The battle system is a turn-based tactical RPG. You have your characters on one side, the enemies on the other. You move up to them and punch them. When attacking you can select between Rush attacks (quickly fills your EXE Gauge), Power attacks (deals heavy damage), and Break attacks (significantly lowers the enemy's Guard Points, so your Power attacks do more damage, can also inflict Guard Break). There are also SP moves, which are akin to abilities and spells, and EXE Drives, which are your special moves that use up your EXE Gauge's charges. Another handy feature is that all the CPU characters (The goddess characters) can use HDD. This transforms your character and dramatically raises all of the stats, for the cost of 20% of your max SP.Oh, the enemies you fight? They're the usual slimes, dragons, flowers, flying whales, dating sims, tetris blocks, and otakus you see in normal RPG's.There are also plenty of things to do on the world map, such as unlocking plans which you use for the Remake System, a mechanic that is kind-of like crafting (you trade in materials for a boatload of things), and Disc Development, which are kind-of like accessories, giving you many different buffs depending on the discs you used. There are also many... interesting NPC's which spawn over the course of the game, giving you... insightful comments or just stuff in general.---------------------------------------Now... story:The game puts you in control of Neptune, or as we all know her, Nep-Nep. After a massive fall down from the heavens she finds herself with amnesia. She hears a voice from a so called Histoire, telling her to collect all of the Key Fragments to release her. This leads her on a non-sensical (mostly because of Neptune herself) journey all over Gamindustri. During the game you meet loads of interesting characters, all being completely different from the next. Personally, the characters were my favorite. To mention a few: There's Vert, the mega gamer, MAGES., the Steins;Gate reference  incarnate character, Noire the tsundere... the list goes on. Honestly, the characters themselves can make a purchase worth it, even if you aren't too into cute JRPG's.The game also has a pretty crazy end-game if you get all of the DLC's. If you love difficult bosses and a boatload of things to do, you'll definitely love it. Not even close to finished and still having tons of fun.---------------------------------------However, as many amazing things this game has... it has many flaws (which I've heard the sequels improve on).The first being random difficulty spikes. I don't mean the kind that will make you die a few times... I mean the few that will nearly make you slam your hand into your monitor. The most prominent being as early as chapter 2 (experienced people will know who I am talking about). Then there are also dungeons which are ridiculously easy... followed by one dungeon who happened to have an enemy that could go "viral" and destroy you. Happy times!Re-using dungeon layouts. A lot. With this I mean that you will through-out the story see dungeons that you have already been in, but they have different enemies and harvest points. Optional dungeons follow the same trend, unfortunately. I personally didn't see this as a major thing, but I know some people out there could be irritated by this.Text formatting going off-screen. Yeah that might sound weird, but basically, there are times when the text goes out of the text boxes so you can't see all of it. It happens in dialogue and on descriptions, and it's quite a shame (especially if you have Japanese voices on).---------------------------------------TL;DR SectionPros:+ Amusing nonsensical story*+ Loads of references+ Amazing cast of characters+ Simple yet addicting battle system+ Great end-game full of contentCons:- Crazy difficulty spikes- Repetitive dungeon design- Sloppy text-formatting- Generally a bad PC port + no keyboard prompts, awkward controlsAll-in-all, I would highly recommend this game. Incredible fun, full of laughs and "tense" moments. But do be wary of the few quirks that comes with the PC port, and game in general.*I find the nonsensical story as a positive things because I find that breaking the 4th wall is hilarious,  which this game does /A LOT/.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1is a (slightly-grindy) JRPG developed by Idea Factory and the remake of Hyperdimension Neptunia released for PS3.The four CPUs of Gamindustri are in a bitter fight for the title of the "True Goddess". This battle however has been fought for several hundred years already. When a mysterious voice appears to three of the CPUs, they team up to defeat the remaining one - Purple Heart, Neptune - and knock her down to the main land...If you have already played other main-series titles of this game, the gameplay is pretty much the same as always.For those who don't know, there is a generic overworld from which you access the dungeons, shops and other instances, the dungeons themselves where you can walk around, collect items and fight monsters.Encounters are - rather than being random - based on "symbols" which are enemies on the dungeon map.For combat you can set 3 characters to fight at the same time. During each character's turn, they may move and choose an action (attack, item, etc.). The CPUs still retain their transformed state, HDD, which increases their stats.And then there's even more stuff you can do, but that's nothing worth noting here (and nothing that would change your mind).The grinding isn't as bad as many people make it out to be; a little tactic can help you out. And there's fan-service. Nothing all too significant, but it's definitely there.Do give it a shot if you have no idea what this is, if you know and like the series or you're just bored.Don't if hate the series or Anime in general.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												A pleasant surprise! I thought it would be a bleh anime game that pimps out cute girls to get otakus to buy it. turns out the cute girls part was correct but it's cute enough to keep your interest!PROs- The characters are memorable with a lot of personality.- the fourth wall isn't broken, it's shattered to bits!- The english dub is done well- The puns in the dialogue were changed to better work in english, it's the best part of the game!- Simple game mechanics CONs- very grind happy game...- battle is maybe too basic, you can close your eyes and smash the X button and still win a boss battle- the fourth wall breaking can be hammed in at times so I can see it annoying people- inside jokes that only hardcore gamers would understand.This is a niche game for sure but it's a good one, I got it during the sale for $5 and for that price or even at 50% off would totally recommend it, not so much at full price though.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Hello guys and gals! This is my quick review of Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 (long title XD).Before we begin, I just want to point out that this game has exceeded my expectations. This is one of those games that EVERYONE should try before they judge.While it looks like, what some people consider, "weaboo trash", it's actually an amazing game with great qualities. So, if you like anime-related titles, PICK THIS UP!!!  STORY  Oh man, the story! This game is simply a giant reference to video game culture, so naturally the story has to do with something we like to call THE CONSOLE WAR.Basically, in the land of Gamindustri, each nation (the consoles) are governed by CPU's (console-patron-units) who are obviously fighting for power. They gather power from shares (the people's belief and support). However, one day the tables turn, and our main protagonist,  Neptune  loses her memory, and the Console War slowly dies out...Who is behind this, and why? What happens to Neptune??There's the plot for you.It's simple, honestly. Simplicity is not always considered a "bad thing" especially when you can clearly understand it. This game has a very basic story that isn't too generic, so it will keep you entertained throughout the course of the game.Other than that, the plot goes rather smoothly, with little explanation here and there. It's also quite enjoyable when you see the HUNDREDS of references to video game culture. With this, it's quite amusing :D. CHARACTERS The characters in this game is what really sets it apart from other games. A good game MUST have good characters, right?In Neptunia, each character is notsomuch  relatable  as they are  hilarious . They each have their own unique traits and designs. The designs of the characters in this game ALSO reference game culture, so not only is it entertaining to nit-pick the references but they are also DISTINGUISHABLE. This is EXTEREMELY important for any character design. You look at these characters and you're like "Neptunia".Not only that, each character has a deep personality that is unique in itself.The main CPUs, while no backstories are present, are the most developed in the series, so people usually will just toss the other characters to the side.From what I have seen, the back-characters are all still unique, but some are not unique enough to be really "loved". The character "Broccoli" is an example.So, really, I adore these characters, as whatever adventures they go on I want to be a part of. Excellent. GAMEPLAY  OH MAN  the gameplay, everyone's main reason to read a review.It's honestly an easy to understand, yet hard to master system of turn-based combat. Turn-based, in this game, is actually very great, and you can formulate a ton of strategies to destroy your foes.I honestly thought it would become very repetitive and boring, but new things are added and new strategies are discovered. And with a ton of characters to play around with and a ton of enemies to destroy, it got VERY fun VERY fast.Overall, the gameplay is fairly simple: take turns using one of three attack style, use an item, maybe turn HDD (hard-drive-divinity) use EXE drives and strategically use elemental attacks or physical/magic attacks.What saddens me is that I never saw a use to ACTUALLY pay attention to elements and what kind of attack it was. The game did not seem to really care, even though the imense amounts of armor says otherwise.Honestly, you don't need to pay THAT much attention to it, but I like compex systems, so I guess I should have tried it. So, if you do get this game, prepare to formulate a team with different abilities and movesets! These two RPG traits are actually not that taken-advantage-of in this game. Mostly just Area Attacks and break/defensive damage. BUT, it is possible to see a ton of strategy in this game, you just have to want it. ENJOYMENT I sincerely enjoyed this title, beginning to end. It was a fun ride with so many combinations of characters and moves that I honestly did not explore probably most of it. The acheivements for this game are also great, while grindy at times. This game does not require too much grind, until you get to the point where you want to obtain Millionaire (which in that case, good luck).Whenever I played it I just knew what my next goal was, and knew my strategy for it. Even the visual novel-style cutscenes had me hooked. It's really an addicting game. PROS Addicting gamplayFun mechanicsUnique charactersHOURS of game timeCan-be complex RPGFantastic RPG elements and Plan systemHilarious CONS Utilizes some mechanics poorlyGameplay is monotonous for someNo full English DubFor me, a glitch where an enemy never attacks, so I have to restartRe-flushed enemy/dungeon designs VERDICT:  WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? Call me a weeb if you want, but THIS GAME is just a masterpeice in it's own right.I got it on mega-sale (all games for around $27), but the full price is honestly still worth it.So, on sale or not, BUY IT.You won't regret it. Thanks for your time if you read all this!!!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I wanted to like this game, I really did. However I simply couldn't like it.First of all, there is a lot of dialogue (most of it not even dubbed in english except for the important parts) and it can get a bit tedious wanting to play the game and having to go through text and text. If you're into anime humor then you will not find anything wrong with this, but if you don't, it's definately gonnaThe other thing to keep in mind is the gameplay. It's not bad and stinging combos can be satisfying, however, for some reason the game can get really difficult. Sometimes you can get early enemies that do so much damage even if you're at the beginning of the game. Makes you think if you should even be there or if you should just start grinding for exp.Also, the amount of DLC is absolutely ridiculous. Almost reaching COD levels.However, I do have to say the concept is genius. It's basically a console war with anime characters.If you like anime humor, some grinding and JRPGs in general, you might like this game.

												After seeing two piles of dung in the form of ARK and The Isle this is refreshing to give a review that I can acturally recommend.This is a paraody game on JRPGs and gaming in general with a cute and funny storyline. It has some of the best sound tracks I have heard on a JRPG for the PC that I can rock out to like a 90's head banger. This kirin is in dance mode everytime I hear the opening theme. THAT SAYS ALOT! The graphics are 2d in for the encounters yet the disloge is just too funny that the shallowness of that style melts away. The combat is 3d with a combo attack system that is not only easy for the keyboard but makes it a blast to slam out quick burst action. Too bad you have mess with button configuration the work with WADS+QE but when you have it it feels like a PC MMO not unlike FF14! Maybe the developers can hot fix this? This game series is worth every penny and I would strongly suggest this game to anyone who loves action comody and JRPGs. and...NAPTUNE SHOVELS IT INTO SAILOR MOON  SO BLOODY HARD! GO PURPLE HEART, YOU GOT A NEW FAN!

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												Okay, let's get this out of the way first. This series is very, very moe-centric. It's also overflowing with fan service, high pitched voices, and quests about increasing the boob size of various characters, some of which are clearly designed to be underage. Honestly, it was nearly too much for me and I almost couldn't get into the game. I'm not saying these are negatives (other than the underage girls thing, come on), but if you're not someone who enjoys bunches of anime girls with giant breasts, you should understand that is what this series is all about.Well, that and countless videogame references. It's going way out of its way to be meta as crap.That being said, it's a rather interesting and fun rpg. There are tons of items to collect to craft various plans that can change the game in a ton of different waves. You can add items to the shop, change what monsters are in a dungeon, add new playable characters, and even totally new game mechanics.Sadly, every game in this series (every game by this developer even) is a lazy port. There are no video options other than resolution. While playing in full screen with a controller, if your mouse moves at all, you will scroll menus and the like. I don't know why it doesn't disable the mouse if I have the input set to the controller. The game performs just fine, I am just calling it a lazy port because of the lack of options that pc users expect.That complaint aside, I really enjoy the gameplay. I end up skipping a lot of the dialogue because there is so freakin' much of it, and most of it isn't anything to do with the story line. Various NPC chat bubbles will pop up all over the map, and sometimes they give you stuff. More often than not, they waste a bunch of your time clearing them all off. Re;birth 1 isn't as bad about this as 2 and 3 are, though.Something else I skip a lot, thanks to a pretty rad feature, is combat animations. If you hold LB, animations won't play and you can end fights in seconds. It makes grinding a lot less painful, because some of the special attack animations are longer than I'd like. That being said, most of them look impressive.Oh, it should also be noted that the DLC for this game, and the others in the series, can make you crazy overpowered so you should be careful not to ruin your fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												TL;DR- Wonderfully remastered- Brings the battle system from Sisters Generation (Hyperdimension Neptunia 2)- Enjoyable soundtrack- New game plus- Lotsa MMO type grinding, leveling, crafting and much more- Eng Dub and Jap Sub- SKIPPABLE DIALOGUEWow this game has made a huge impact on me and is very quickly becoming one of my new favourite games. The story itself taken from the idea of "console war" into a fictional setting is just super interesting in the way they've personified each console/game companies both old, discontinued and current. I personally haven't played the game through Jap-sub but during my experience with the Eng-Dub my god the english cast chosen to voice these characters really bring their personalities to life they've done such a wonderful job. All the little nods to other games, consoles just make this game super enjoyable and had me laughing or smiling almost all the time, it's quirky and fantastic.I had played the original on PS3 but found it was too laggy for my liking so I had dropped it quickly, did some reading and apparently there's a ton more dialogue embedded into the story which I'm upset I couldn't stick it through the laggy PS3 version to replay it on console for finding those changes and noticing them it would make it such a better experience for myself. With that being said this game runs smoothly and looks wonderful as well they did such a good job porting it to PC.If you manage to buy the DLC I'd recommend not using said characters that come with the DLC until after you beat the game first, it made the playthrough a tad easier with being able to access the special "HDD" form right form the get-go with these characters so being that when you're up to missions were you're not supposed to have it, it's more or less a breeze but that's just me, play however you like the characters are awesome, you'll still die if you don't grind enough basically.I'm still grinding for the rest of the achievements and grabbing the other characters so I'm not yet done with this game!If you love super cute anime grills, turn based combat system, transformations, MMO type grinding and a wonderful story that will keep you hooked then this is a must buy.P.S. Noire and Plutia are best grills.

												I am in chapter three of this game and loving it. Combat feels similar to FFX-2 and the characters are fun, sarcastic, and generally adorable. There is too much fan service but it is not way over the top and they do a good job of not sexualizing the magical girl forms although they are rediculous about the teenage "Goddess" forms. Overall the story is fairly standard jrpg fare up to this point but the crafting system is a ton of fun and the pacing is great.One tip, if you grab this game go ahead and put down the $6.00 for the expanded content. You get two extra playable characters and wardrobes for both of them. That alone is worth it if you ask me. Anyway I hope you give it a go and enjoy it as much as I am -xoxo Sarah

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Damn it all, this game has brought out my inner weeaboo. Other than the anime style though, all in all a great well rounded, fun RPG. Stunning looking special moves, awesome HDD Transformations (Basically Mega Evolutions), no overly complicated battle interface, simple as you have a certain area that is shown that you can put damage into, how you aim it depends on whether or not you will take out 1, or take out 5. Story is compelling, full of comedy, puns, and many MANY references. Fun Plan system which lets you alter the game however you like. Enemies too hard? Use the Plan system to weaken them and give you a little edge. Enemies too weak for your tastes? Turn that♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up to 11 with the Plan system. The Plan system is basically like built in mods, that you unlock over time. You like character customization? Boom, there are different outfits for all the useable characters that not only change their clothing, but their hair color and eye color...... Ok I will admit it's not the BEST character customization, but it's still fun in it's own aspects. The game has a great leveling system too, each new dungeon you enter obtains enemies that are not only stronger, but actually give out enough more exp than the enemies in the last dungeon that you don't hit a ceiling, and end up having to spend a good amount of time to gain just 1 level. An example of this is, you need to gain a total of 40,000 Exp to level up, the enemies at the most recent dungeon give out around 2,000-3,000 Exp per battle. At most takes about 10-15 minutes to level up your characters. (Did I mention as long as they are in your party and are alive, they all gain equal experience? It's like Exp. Share from Pokemon, but actually an EQUAL share. Cool right?) All in all I'd give this game a 10/10, Great, compelling, comedic, all around amazing story along with a great battle system and cool looking special attacks and HDD Transformations, with great plot development, fun and challenging boss fights, tons of references from titles such as Pokemon, Space Invaders, (an anime that has a contract signing little pink thing, I forget the name of it), comedic stereotypes, and a fair share of fourth-wall breaks, leaves this game as a must buy game for almost anyone! Definitely my new absolute favorite JRPG game. I've had it for barely a day and a half, and I already have 18.3 hours spent into this beauty. 10/10 would recommend, definitely worth the price. 10/10 would binge-play this game.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												  The game is ported to PC from the Playstation Vita handheld, and the ending result its not great. Crashes on Startup, the cutscenes are not rendered in 1080p, the keyboard and mouse controls are awful, when you try connecting an gamepad it struggles to read. I had to spent a lot of time looking up stuff online to solve this issues and messing around in the options menu before actually getting it to work properly.  Gameplay side aspects are great, the combat mechanics, crafting, questing, grinding in general are very well implemented.   The whole Gaming Industry analogy thing is also amazing. Love all the references to the video game companies (Sony, Microsoft, Nintendo, Sega ...), to other games, and gaming related things in general.Overall, i would recommend if you have the patience to fix the game before actually getting to play it.

												Very addicting games. It's like the real japanese RPG.Why? Because we need to beat lot more monster and level-up before completing the Event like fighting with a boss or such.The art is good, Moving girl in conversation is the best thing though.Album and Audio is OK too. It's a nice and worth to play game, well originally it's a Vita's game but still, I enjoyed it more to be able to play it on PC specially in steam.Wish you get a good gaming time, goodluck with trying the game.P.S. : It'll be better if there's an auto-save. It's a pain sometimes when you're dead and you'll auto-continue on the last time you "saved" the game. The worse case is when we forget to save the game, we need to re-play it. Even if you got the SKIP button on the conversation it's still a pain to re-fight the monster we've been defeated. That's it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												One game I was addicted to when I was a child was Final Fantasy VIII.  Running around and getting into turn-based fights with exotic creatures and using interesting magical attacks with epic animations was pretty fun for me.  I also came to love anime and all things cute.  This game combines those and adds a lot of media references, grinding to unlock items to play dressup with a large cast of characters, and a metaphorical story about consoles fighting against piracy.The controls are awkward and take some getting used to, only about half of the English VO was ever done, and the combat can get a bit repetitive.  In spite of the issues it has, I have enjoyed more than enough hours of playing to say this is a great game.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 is a gem of a game that deserves at least two playthrough's. One for the Normal Ending, the second for the True. I was pleasently surprised to hear about a remake after completing the original. The remake addresses A LOT of the issues that the first game had. The battle system is more involved and the dungeons actually stand apart from one another. The characters and dialogue hold up very well for those interested in videogame references. All of the additions to this remake are worth the buy. Purchase the game while it's on sale, if you have any doubts.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Bought this as a bit of a joke since it was dirt cheap in the Summer Sale. Ended up playing it for hours.HDN RB1 takes place in Gamindustri, a world loosely based on consoles. Each nation is led by a 'CPU' which is revered as a goddess and all the goddesses have been embroiled in a Console War. The whole game is wrapped in this silliness and you'll probably have fun finding all the game references, in-jokes and fourth wall breaking. If you're looking for a serious JRPG look elsewhere but don't be fooled by the cute appearance of HDN.At its heart HDN is a very competent JRPG with a pretty interesting battle system that lets you use 3 characters and have another 3 at the 'back' (off screen) who you can use for boosts and assist attacks. Certain characters have access to 'HDD' which is a powered-up version (think super saiyan?) and there's also a lot of different playstyles between characters. Boss fights can be extremely tough- one of my few issues with the game is that the difficulty curve doesn't exist. It jumps and drops all the time which can be pretty annoying.The only other issues I have are that the dungeons are typically short and re-used over and over and sometimes in important story segments you have to go a long time between saves, sometimes fighting multiple bosses before you can save again which is pretty harsh if you're not prepared.Overall I was completely surprised by this and would really recommend it to anyone who wants a JRPG and/or something with a sense of humour....Desu desu desu

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												After beat and complete this game (CPU Candidates, Ultimate Weapons, Gear, Processors and Outfits) I feel its fair to review this game right now. And I would give it a 8.5/10For me the most important thing are the mechanics for grinding, leveling and battle system on any RPG. And as this was my first 3D turn based RPG, it was fair easy and quick to understand to truly enjoy the battles each time.The difficulty is important too and even when this is the fastest RPG I beat in real time it requires a good grinding between bosses as those can be pretty tough; don´t expect your nowadays easy RPGs were you can beat the story mode without even grind at all.The music is attractive and keeps you entertained while playing to fit each battle, specially the boss's theme as it should be. But I still cant help myself and feel like one specific track was directly taken from a Phantasy Star's game but I cant land my finger on wich one or be 100% sure about it.My only disappointments were:-Enemy's skins: not too many enemy so the "colors" change for map and difficulty.-Maps: More than once, the dungeon's repeat the same maps don´t brings you high hopes when you visit a new dungeon for the first time but you already know where to expect monsters and the though enemy.-Lack of interaction: there isn't just enough time or events to get to know all the characters in the game as good as I would like to, I guess is to expect since this is a portable remake but it feels a little unfair.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												This is what you expect from a port, very fluid and responsive controls and UI, 60 fps nativly, and to top it off, a great game. The story is great, full of refrences to japanese culture. The characters are entertaining, albeit some minor characters literally never explain why they are there or who they are. Combat is lightning fast, most battles being over in sub 30 seconds, provided you skip attack animations. If you really want to, you can replay the game for quite some time, mostly grinding to kill super bosses. Personally, I have a backlog to play, so the 45 hours or so it took me to beat the main story was time well spent. Honestly, a great JSRPG, any fans of the genre should pick it up, especially for the price point.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												A very good RPG based in a video game-like universe. There are many references to real things and video games such as Dr Pepper, Vocaloid, Touhou Project, Mario or even Metal Gear Solid. The game also allows you to customize the outfit of each of your characters: you have a large range of outfits and hats for each character (except one or two, maybe). Some of these outfits are inspired from anime, such as Steins;Gate or Senran Kagura.Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 offers a wide range of characters (which are unlocked as you progress) which all have different skills and gear - entirely customizable.This game is fairly long - the DLC's (which are quite inexpensive) can extend the game's length. Though if you aren't willing to buy the DLC's, you can still enjoy the game by going for the achievements (I did!), crafting every item possible or completing every Colosseum challenge and Quests. This game will provide you many hours of intensive Nepping. Can't have enough of that.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												Is there an anime/videogame character stronger than Nep?And I'm not talking about MK2 Neptune equipped with the Mecha-Nep Blade, Sharicite, and Goddess Bangle. I'm not talking about Victory Neptune with the Holy Fang Blade, Histy's Bookmark and Archebangle either. Hell, I'm not even talking about Lv.99 Re;Birth1 Neptune in Purple Heart form (with full EXE Drive gauge, EXE Neptune Break, MAX Lily rank Falcom as partner for the Ignore Enemy Traits and the use of Icicle Spear and Cyclone attacks), equipped with the Fury (Eryn) Fairy Fencer F weapon, Candidate Ring, Monkey Bracelet, and the complete set of Angel or Devil Processor Units. I’m also not talking about Re;Birth1 Lv.999 Neptune in Purple Heart form with 100% shares in Planeptune and the Lost Purple Processor Units (which is capable of destroying Arfoire solo and makes her more powerful than the other CPUs combined) equipped with the Kiryu Sword, Shining Ring, CPU Ring and an Infinidisc with Act Fast Lv.5, Gradual HP Recovery Lv.5 and Physical Defense+ Lv.5 (with full EXE Drive gauge, EXE HDD: Neptune, MAX Lily rank CyberConnect2 as partner for the Ignore Enemy Traits and Shorten Wait effects and the use of Exploding Yama and Major Lightning Cut).

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												If you're looking at this and you haven't bought the game yet, then you're doing something wrong.All jokes aside, this is a great game and it gives off a very persona vibe. Though this game may seem to be lacking in alot of the persona aspects, it makes up for them with its charm. Sooo many gaming puns, soo many anime references, it's all around a great time even if you're not familiar with the subjects.So, how is this persona-ish you might ask? Well it's got the same dungeon crawler qualities, and similar adventure mechanics that you'd expect from a persona game though with a very different combat style. You run around dungeons in your 3D characters model (Yes, you can dress up your character) and run up to enimes to iniate the combat events which brings you into the battle fase. If you've played persona you will easily grasp the core concepts of the aventure aspect. The combat however is very different and god is it complex. Read the tutorials... they will definitely help.The story of this game series is astounding, fun and immersive. They did a great job and every line was interesting and added to the overall experience of the game. Then there's the voice acting... holy♥♥♥♥♥♥was that voice acting AMAZING! The art design... AMAZING! The animation... AMAZING!Seriously, how can you not have already bought this game?

												This game is great--If you look past the fanservice that is. There's lots of fanservice, and the characters even occasionally point it out for some added humor.Funny characters, fun gameplay, and cheap add-ons that are easily worth their price. If you play it, don't expect a masterpiece story, but expect masterfully written characters that you either love, or downright despise (Looking at you, Thunder♥♥♥♥♥♥Not really much else to sayHave a Nepping wonderful day you beautiful people.EDIT: Be warned, the grind is real. If you're going for all the achievements, the one to get 100,000,000 credits will break you, and getting to the maximum level is a challenge all on it's own. 999 levels doesn't sound like it would take 100+ hours, but it does. This game is a completionist hell. Otherwise, still an amazing game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												In the game industry of our world we have seen countless companies come and go, bringing us amazing consoles, epic games, and so much enjoyment and innovation. From the simple joysticks and clunky cartridges of the past, to the sleek disc-based consoles of today, videogaming over the ages has told a rich and and storied saga. Now imagine if you will, a world where people live and die based on the market shares of their respective game comnpanies. A world where software pirates and modchip makers are the scourge of the seas. A world ruled by digitally deified divas who symbolize the hopes and dreams of their console nations. Welcome to the digital frontier of Gamindustri!Released last year on the Playstation Vita, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 has now been ported onto the PC, and is offered for sale exclusively on Steam. The entire experience is here, with all the trimmings (including plenty of DLC to buy!). Sadly it's been a little clunky so far, with many issues popping up here and there, but Idea Factory has been fast to listen to fan feedback and fix everything up! It's good to see they care about their fans at this level, some companies (COUGHSQUAREENIXCOUGH) can;t seem to take a hint about what their fans think. I'm confident though that IF knows their fanbase, as they have handled everything smoothly thus far.Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 marks the fourth outing for the series, and though it may be a reboot it is also the longest, most hilariously off the wall and over the top game to grace the series yet. If Hyperdimension Neptunia mk2 was considered a reboot of the original, then perhaps that makes Hyperdimension Neptuinia Re:Birth1 a reboot of a reboot! This literal rebirth of the original game takes the original story, polishes it up a few notches, and sticks it on top of the gameplay system that made Hyperdimension Neptunia: Victory so great.To be brutally honest, the original Hyperdimension Neptunia for PS3 was an absolute soul-breaking slog, with hours of grinding and frankly boring combat dragging the experience on. The only saving grace was its story, which made the most of things with its masterful console war allegory. Thankfully having been moved over to the gameplay stylings of Victory, Re:Birth1 is propelled high and above its clunky progenitor. With the far more exciting battle system on offer in this entry, traveling through the games myriad dungeons and leveling up no longer feels like such a chore. Unrestrained by the formerly boring gameplay, the story is now free to take center stage.When it comes right down to it, Re;Birth1 is STILL a shining example of that the series can offer. The PC library could definitely use more JRPG experiences like these, as it's mainly been a bland morass of western RPGS until now. I for one would gladly go for every Neptunia adventure again if they were to be ported to the PC. Now get on Steam and buy this awesome game, or I'll send Iris Heart after you!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Damn it all, this game has brought out my inner weeaboo. Other than the anime style though, all in all a great well rounded, fun RPG. Stunning looking special moves, awesome HDD Transformations (Basically Mega Evolutions), no overly complicated battle interface, simple as you have a certain area that is shown that you can put damage into, how you aim it depends on whether or not you will take out 1, or take out 5. Story is compelling, full of comedy, puns, and many MANY references. Fun Plan system which lets you alter the game however you like. Enemies too hard? Use the Plan system to weaken them and give you a little edge. Enemies too weak for your tastes? Turn that♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up to 11 with the Plan system. The Plan system is basically like built in mods, that you unlock over time. You like character customization? Boom, there are different outfits for all the useable characters that not only change their clothing, but their hair color and eye color...... Ok I will admit it's not the BEST character customization, but it's still fun in it's own aspects. The game has a great leveling system too, each new dungeon you enter obtains enemies that are not only stronger, but actually give out enough more exp than the enemies in the last dungeon that you don't hit a ceiling, and end up having to spend a good amount of time to gain just 1 level. An example of this is, you need to gain a total of 40,000 Exp to level up, the enemies at the most recent dungeon give out around 2,000-3,000 Exp per battle. At most takes about 10-15 minutes to level up your characters. (Did I mention as long as they are in your party and are alive, they all gain equal experience? It's like Exp. Share from Pokemon, but actually an EQUAL share. Cool right?) All in all I'd give this game a 10/10, Great, compelling, comedic, all around amazing story along with a great battle system and cool looking special attacks and HDD Transformations, with great plot development, fun and challenging boss fights, tons of references from titles such as Pokemon, Space Invaders, (an anime that has a contract signing little pink thing, I forget the name of it), comedic stereotypes, and a fair share of fourth-wall breaks, leaves this game as a must buy game for almost anyone! Definitely my new absolute favorite JRPG game. I've had it for barely a day and a half, and I already have 18.3 hours spent into this beauty. 10/10 would recommend, definitely worth the price. 10/10 would binge-play this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I bought this with a lot of hesitation, because I wasn't a fan of the original title. I liked the idea of creating a parody of the whole console wars. The story begins with 4 sister goddesses who were born from one original one (possibly the Atari?). However, for long as they can remember, the 4 goddesses engage in a long battle and eventually, Neptune gets knocked out and sent flying to the land below. She loses her memory like a stereotypical JRPG character and begins finding a way to regain her memories, only to eventually unite all 4 goddesses together to fight the main enemy.The story overall was mediocre. Despite all of the cracks about consoles and poking fun of various game/anime stereotypes, (the characters are all a form of one) the game itself was ironically still one. However, it's all about the characters and they're all unique in their own way. Of course, there's a lot of fanfare and random breast physics. Like how IF has jiggle physics is beyond me..But it's there. There's no real "movie" sequences in the game, but only still pictures that only use those jiggle "physics" to compliment the sequences. However, although there's a bit of fanfare, the game doesn't focus TOO much on breast jokes. There's a bit more game jokes as the game centers around the idea of poking fun of console wars. The idea of having flash cards like the R4 as enemies made me laugh.The music makes you feel as if you're in a digital Japanese setting. Though I'm not a fan of JPOP, I kind of enjoyed the music in the fields and for some characters which were all more instrumental. The opening and ending sequences made me groan.What helps this game shine is the battle system. It's turn based, but it's fast paced and flashy. You choose sequences of attacks, or a special move to either break the enemy defense, or simply deplete the health. By breaking the enemy shield, your attacks will do a lot more damage. You also build an EXE meter which allows you to unleash devastating attacks to enemies. The difficulty of the game bounces back and forth from ridiculously easy to managably hard. There was never one time where I felt like I had to adjust my strategy to make the battle easier. You'll just need to grind some levels to make sure the enemies can be defeated.There's a huge cast of characters in this game, most of which will join your team. Like any fanfare game, there's also a number of costumes and accessories for your characters. You want the swimsuit? Well, yeah, that's there. There's also costumes that are inspired by certain characters of various anime/games as well. Most of the items are created through plans where you have to grind out materials for. The materials aren't tough to get either. You won't have to grind out the same monster several times before getting one piece you need.It was pretty easy to reach 100% achievements for this game. Maxing out your level doesn't feel like much of a grind, especially since there's some enemies that give a ridiculous amount of experience. Overall, I was happy to give this game another chance and it managed to get me excited enough to play the second one when it releases on Steam.

												This is what you expect from a port, very fluid and responsive controls and UI, 60 fps nativly, and to top it off, a great game. The story is great, full of refrences to japanese culture. The characters are entertaining, albeit some minor characters literally never explain why they are there or who they are. Combat is lightning fast, most battles being over in sub 30 seconds, provided you skip attack animations. If you really want to, you can replay the game for quite some time, mostly grinding to kill super bosses. Personally, I have a backlog to play, so the 45 hours or so it took me to beat the main story was time well spent. Honestly, a great JSRPG, any fans of the genre should pick it up, especially for the price point.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												A very good RPG based in a video game-like universe. There are many references to real things and video games such as Dr Pepper, Vocaloid, Touhou Project, Mario or even Metal Gear Solid. The game also allows you to customize the outfit of each of your characters: you have a large range of outfits and hats for each character (except one or two, maybe). Some of these outfits are inspired from anime, such as Steins;Gate or Senran Kagura.Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 offers a wide range of characters (which are unlocked as you progress) which all have different skills and gear - entirely customizable.This game is fairly long - the DLC's (which are quite inexpensive) can extend the game's length. Though if you aren't willing to buy the DLC's, you can still enjoy the game by going for the achievements (I did!), crafting every item possible or completing every Colosseum challenge and Quests. This game will provide you many hours of intensive Nepping. Can't have enough of that.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
When I bought this game I really didn't expect anything.I tend to have a habit of buying random cutesy anime games, even if they are decent at best. So I bought this, expecting to play it in spite of people... but I ended up really liking it.Like, really, really liking it. I expected this to be a decent (if even that) JRPG but after a few hours I was hooked with the ridiculously likable characters, non-sensical story, and simple-yet-interesting mechanics.---------------------------------------This being on PC, the PC port stuff comes first:It's not that good. It's not good at all really, but it does run at 60FPS, goes up to 1080p, and has borderless window as an option. No real graphics options. It's still quite obvious that it's a port of a Vita game, but the game still looks really nice, in my opinion. Do be aware that there are no button prompts in-game for keyboard controls. It always displays with Xbox buttons. I prefer playing the game with the 360 controller. If you play with the keyboard, note that if you can get past the fact that there are no help prompts, and that the controls are kind of awkward, the game is still very much playable.---------------------------------------Now, onto gameplay:The battle system is a turn-based tactical RPG. You have your characters on one side, the enemies on the other. You move up to them and punch them. When attacking you can select between Rush attacks (quickly fills your EXE Gauge), Power attacks (deals heavy damage), and Break attacks (significantly lowers the enemy's Guard Points, so your Power attacks do more damage, can also inflict Guard Break). There are also SP moves, which are akin to abilities and spells, and EXE Drives, which are your special moves that use up your EXE Gauge's charges. Another handy feature is that all the CPU characters (The goddess characters) can use HDD. This transforms your character and dramatically raises all of the stats, for the cost of 20% of your max SP.Oh, the enemies you fight? They're the usual slimes, dragons, flowers, flying whales, dating sims, tetris blocks, and otakus you see in normal RPG's.There are also plenty of things to do on the world map, such as unlocking plans which you use for the Remake System, a mechanic that is kind-of like crafting (you trade in materials for a boatload of things), and Disc Development, which are kind-of like accessories, giving you many different buffs depending on the discs you used. There are also many... interesting NPC's which spawn over the course of the game, giving you... insightful comments or just stuff in general.---------------------------------------Now... story:The game puts you in control of Neptune, or as we all know her, Nep-Nep. After a massive fall down from the heavens she finds herself with amnesia. She hears a voice from a so called Histoire, telling her to collect all of the Key Fragments to release her. This leads her on a non-sensical (mostly because of Neptune herself) journey all over Gamindustri. During the game you meet loads of interesting characters, all being completely different from the next. Personally, the characters were my favorite. To mention a few: There's Vert, the mega gamer, MAGES., the Steins;Gate reference  incarnate character, Noire the tsundere... the list goes on. Honestly, the characters themselves can make a purchase worth it, even if you aren't too into cute JRPG's.The game also has a pretty crazy end-game if you get all of the DLC's. If you love difficult bosses and a boatload of things to do, you'll definitely love it. Not even close to finished and still having tons of fun.---------------------------------------However, as many amazing things this game has... it has many flaws (which I've heard the sequels improve on).The first being random difficulty spikes. I don't mean the kind that will make you die a few times... I mean the few that will nearly make you slam your hand into your monitor. The most prominent being as early as chapter 2 (experienced people will know who I am talking about). Then there are also dungeons which are ridiculously easy... followed by one dungeon who happened to have an enemy that could go "viral" and destroy you. Happy times!Re-using dungeon layouts. A lot. With this I mean that you will through-out the story see dungeons that you have already been in, but they have different enemies and harvest points. Optional dungeons follow the same trend, unfortunately. I personally didn't see this as a major thing, but I know some people out there could be irritated by this.Text formatting going off-screen. Yeah that might sound weird, but basically, there are times when the text goes out of the text boxes so you can't see all of it. It happens in dialogue and on descriptions, and it's quite a shame (especially if you have Japanese voices on).---------------------------------------TL;DR SectionPros:+ Amusing nonsensical story*+ Loads of references+ Amazing cast of characters+ Simple yet addicting battle system+ Great end-game full of contentCons:- Crazy difficulty spikes- Repetitive dungeon design- Sloppy text-formatting- Generally a bad PC port + no keyboard prompts, awkward controlsAll-in-all, I would highly recommend this game. Incredible fun, full of laughs and "tense" moments. But do be wary of the few quirks that comes with the PC port, and game in general.*I find the nonsensical story as a positive things because I find that breaking the 4th wall is hilarious,  which this game does /A LOT/.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Played about 8 hours, and for people who don't like to read, here's a summary: "Great Turn-Based JRPG, with great snarky and natural dialouge, while naturally presenting references to the Game Industry and Games in general. Pros: +Amazing Dialouge+References don't feel forced+Kawaii Desu~ Anime Grillz +Varied monster designs, and accesories.Neutral:.Combat System (Although fun, nothing innovative. Standard turnbased combat with the exception of positioning).Music (Can get annoying but that's just my opinion).Character Design (You can easily tell them apart, but other than the main "CPU's" alternative forms, they are just above average)Negatives:-Save Points: Although there are no save points in the game, and you have to manually save in the world map and certain locations in the dungeons; sometimes boss-fights may start right after miniboss fights. In my opinion, it was a tad bit too difficult, and slightly frustrating. -Accesories: Although most accesories don't add to your stats, it's quite hard to save up your money to purchase the costumes, when you're in dire need of items and equipment.All in all, I would rate the game 7/10, and this was certainly worth my $15. If you like cute animu grillz fighting together with natural dialouge and amazing voice acting, topped off with natural game references, then get this.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
 A stylish game, not afraid of Punning everyone.Before starting this game, I asked my friends, who already play it, what were they thoughts about it.I've got very mixed responses, so I've decided to see for myself what this anime-styled game is all about.GraphicsWithout going into too much details, the game is quite nice, the dungeons are colorful, menus look good, and the character/mob models look amazing. You can tell the creators put a lot of work into some of them. On the other hand quite a lot of those model and dungeon assets are re-used. It'd be a bit more acceptable if this recycling was done only partially and not throughout most of the game. It takes away the freshness that the game had going for itself. But, oh well.GameplayThe game's a typical turn-based japanese RPG. Though it suffers from some balancing issues, especially at the beginning  (a big raise in difficulty) or when the player farms items (the game becomes much easier), not to mention the dlc stuff, which I will not cover. Aside from dungeon crawling to progress through the story, the other thing the player gets to do is, to put it simply, craft new dungeons, item recipes and game difficulty modifiers. It's weird, but if you don't spend too much time on it, it is a fun thing to do.  On the flipside, perfectionists might find this game tiresome, with the amount of farming needed to unlock all of the items (mostly clothing and accesories). And also, while the menus look stylish and all that, ya gotta get used to how they are organised, they are a bit untidy, to say the least. Some of the tutorials could also be a bit more detailed, but I guess it's a problem with more than just his JRPG... Sounds I've got nothing bad to say about this game's music or sounds, while there are some default JRPG sounds here and there a casual player won't notice a thing, the voice-acting is as squeaky as needed, heck, even the English voices aren't half bad. And the BGM... they aren't half bad, as long as you don't listen to the same tune for 20 hours while farming, or something. Story The game's setting is weird, because it's a game about... the game industry. Yeah. And the consoles are portrayed as anime chicks, which is probably the game's biggest selling point. And now ya must be thinking "Oh, so that's why this sad fellow spent all of his precious time farming for clothing". *Achem* The story's not too bad, it's not deep, but some will find the plot to be engulfing, and will crave for more, which, lucky for them, there's plenty more of in new titles and the anime adaptation. Conclusion The game is not perfect, players looking for a challenging RPG with a lot of drama might need to look elsewhere. But while it's not the best, the visuals are great, you can tell the authors poured a lot of love into the game, with the good looking character models and their animations. And with all that said, I'd recommend this game for people who might be looking for something similiar yet a bit off to what they are used to. Not recommended for people with no sense of humour and low tolerance to squeaky/high-pitched voices.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I have no idea why I like this game so much. It's super girly, too colourful, and the dialogue that TRIES to be funny is annoying.I guess I'm just really in love with the battle system. It feels rewarding to learn new moves for each character and add them to your combo strings. I love RPG's that give you the option to have more than just one basic attack during battle. In each combo string, you have three choices: 1) Guard Break 2) Rush and 3) Power Attack. Your goal is to break down the guard of your enemies so that your power attacks have more...well...POWER! However, if you choose to use Rush attacks, it can work towards building your EXE bars.EXE bars give you the opportunity to have a 5th attack in your combo string, and there's 4 different levels. The more EXE bars you have filled up, the higher level EXE attacks you can use. EXE Skills on the other hand are also beautifully animated super attacks, kinda like Limit Breaks from Final Fantasy, that you can use to dish out a ton of damage. They are lot of fun to unlock, as well as use once you've broken down the enemy's guard.The story of Hyperdimension Neptunia is nothing really special. Apparently all the Goddesses and CPU's are supposed to represent current gen consoles like XBOX360, PS3 and Wii-U. The main character Neptune I think is supposed to represent you, the player, trying to find a way to mend the bad blood between them all and have them unite the land of Gameindustri.The dialogue in this game can sometimes get annoying with absolutely no direction in the story line. I really LOVE the parts where actual conflict occurs and moves the story forward, and although it's a basic plot of uniting nation leaders through combat against a common foe, I actually enjoy it. Which is weird since I normally look for something deeper in storylines like something akin to Life is Strange where they tackle the social issues youth face on a daily basis.Want a deep storyline? Ain't gonna find it here. Want a lot of useless dialogue that tries to be cute, funny, and cheeky? You got RIGHT HERE and I hate it. Yet this is the game I've played the most in my entire Steam library? Why? The battle system is awesome, and so is the PLAN system, where you can hunt and gather various items in order to unlock a variety of things: extra dungeons, extra enemies per dungeon, new item harvest per dungeon, other aid items, weapons etc etc etc the list goes on.Despite of my deep deep hatred for the pointless dialogues about every character's favourite pudding and their desire for more pudding--I have thoroughly enjoyed this game for its character customization options.

												This game is great--If you look past the fanservice that is. There's lots of fanservice, and the characters even occasionally point it out for some added humor.Funny characters, fun gameplay, and cheap add-ons that are easily worth their price. If you play it, don't expect a masterpiece story, but expect masterfully written characters that you either love, or downright despise (Looking at you, Thunder♥♥♥♥♥♥Not really much else to sayHave a Nepping wonderful day you beautiful people.EDIT: Be warned, the grind is real. If you're going for all the achievements, the one to get 100,000,000 credits will break you, and getting to the maximum level is a challenge all on it's own. 999 levels doesn't sound like it would take 100+ hours, but it does. This game is a completionist hell. Otherwise, still an amazing game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												In the game industry of our world we have seen countless companies come and go, bringing us amazing consoles, epic games, and so much enjoyment and innovation. From the simple joysticks and clunky cartridges of the past, to the sleek disc-based consoles of today, videogaming over the ages has told a rich and and storied saga. Now imagine if you will, a world where people live and die based on the market shares of their respective game comnpanies. A world where software pirates and modchip makers are the scourge of the seas. A world ruled by digitally deified divas who symbolize the hopes and dreams of their console nations. Welcome to the digital frontier of Gamindustri!Released last year on the Playstation Vita, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 has now been ported onto the PC, and is offered for sale exclusively on Steam. The entire experience is here, with all the trimmings (including plenty of DLC to buy!). Sadly it's been a little clunky so far, with many issues popping up here and there, but Idea Factory has been fast to listen to fan feedback and fix everything up! It's good to see they care about their fans at this level, some companies (COUGHSQUAREENIXCOUGH) can;t seem to take a hint about what their fans think. I'm confident though that IF knows their fanbase, as they have handled everything smoothly thus far.Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth1 marks the fourth outing for the series, and though it may be a reboot it is also the longest, most hilariously off the wall and over the top game to grace the series yet. If Hyperdimension Neptunia mk2 was considered a reboot of the original, then perhaps that makes Hyperdimension Neptuinia Re:Birth1 a reboot of a reboot! This literal rebirth of the original game takes the original story, polishes it up a few notches, and sticks it on top of the gameplay system that made Hyperdimension Neptunia: Victory so great.To be brutally honest, the original Hyperdimension Neptunia for PS3 was an absolute soul-breaking slog, with hours of grinding and frankly boring combat dragging the experience on. The only saving grace was its story, which made the most of things with its masterful console war allegory. Thankfully having been moved over to the gameplay stylings of Victory, Re:Birth1 is propelled high and above its clunky progenitor. With the far more exciting battle system on offer in this entry, traveling through the games myriad dungeons and leveling up no longer feels like such a chore. Unrestrained by the formerly boring gameplay, the story is now free to take center stage.When it comes right down to it, Re;Birth1 is STILL a shining example of that the series can offer. The PC library could definitely use more JRPG experiences like these, as it's mainly been a bland morass of western RPGS until now. I for one would gladly go for every Neptunia adventure again if they were to be ported to the PC. Now get on Steam and buy this awesome game, or I'll send Iris Heart after you!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												A really fantastic RPG that fires on most cylinders.  Hyperdimension Neptunia ResemicolonBirthone boasts turn based fighting that still manages to feel active and engaging, multiple crafting systems, good pacing, and tons of character variety and customization.  The story premise is extremely campy and goofy, but it understands this and very rarely takes itself seriously; translating to a plus in my book.  Even the common complaint of grinding is mitigated by craftables that increase exp and loot drops.  I highly recommend making those as soon as possible, as they let you take the game much more freely.  This culminates into a pretty good 20-30 hour game depending on how thorough you want to be. Oh, and when you finish the game? New game + exactly the way you wanted it. Brilliant.The only negatives I can come up with are that enemy variety can get a little stale near the end. Finding the locations of specific drops can also be a nightmare, as the menus don't really like to cooperate.  If you don't really care about getting everything though, you owe it to yourself to pick this game up next Steam Sale.I didn't use any of the DLC on my entire first playthrough, so I don't know if I can recommend that.  I am replaying NG+ with it all on though, and it feels about right so far.  The base game at least is super worth it.P.S. CC2 4 life

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												HDNR;B1 is a parody JRPG with some fanservice and plenty of  "nerdy" references sprinkled in. I'm going to list some things and let you decide whether they're things you like or don't like:  The diologue is quite humorous and witty The english voice acting is pretty bad, but the actors are cute. However, there simply doesn't seem to be line for a lot of parts. The japanese voice acting is just fine (recommended even if you don't speak japanese) The combat is fairly simple. Like a standard JRPG, you run around in an "overworld" and fight groups of monsters when you run into one. Each character has a turn, where you line up the area you can hit in with the enemies, and try to hit as many as possible.  There are LOTS of mechanics going on in this game, and you will likely not know of some until they are explained by the tutorials. You will very likely need to (or want to) grind, however i have found grinding to be fun There are a bunch of cosmetic items (mainly hats/headpieces) for the different characters, as well as outfit changes Waifu Simulator 2015All that being said, I feel this is an absolutely wonderful game if you enjoy JRPGs. It is certainly one of the best, if not THE best, JRPG available on steam, and I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Bought this as a bit of a joke since it was dirt cheap in the Summer Sale. Ended up playing it for hours.HDN RB1 takes place in Gamindustri, a world loosely based on consoles. Each nation is led by a 'CPU' which is revered as a goddess and all the goddesses have been embroiled in a Console War. The whole game is wrapped in this silliness and you'll probably have fun finding all the game references, in-jokes and fourth wall breaking. If you're looking for a serious JRPG look elsewhere but don't be fooled by the cute appearance of HDN.At its heart HDN is a very competent JRPG with a pretty interesting battle system that lets you use 3 characters and have another 3 at the 'back' (off screen) who you can use for boosts and assist attacks. Certain characters have access to 'HDD' which is a powered-up version (think super saiyan?) and there's also a lot of different playstyles between characters. Boss fights can be extremely tough- one of my few issues with the game is that the difficulty curve doesn't exist. It jumps and drops all the time which can be pretty annoying.The only other issues I have are that the dungeons are typically short and re-used over and over and sometimes in important story segments you have to go a long time between saves, sometimes fighting multiple bosses before you can save again which is pretty harsh if you're not prepared.Overall I was completely surprised by this and would really recommend it to anyone who wants a JRPG and/or something with a sense of humour....Desu desu desu

content:
Posted: February 14
												Great for fans of the anime, but IMO terrible from a gameplay standpoint. There is an unbelievable amount of grinding required, but the absolute worst of all (again, IMO) is how unbalanced the dungeon bosses become when they fall below 50% HP. At that exact point they start getting one shot kill crits or SP skills. Hell, I'm seeing SP skills that destroy 2 of my party members while the third is left poisoned/paralysed/skillsealed. All of this only below 50% HP - above that level, there is a normal balance between your party and the boss. Of course, if you've grinded enough. (Speaking of the party, what good is there to have all characters unlocked but only 3 slots x 2 members available?)Overall, I don't think I would have bought this if I knew about this kind of practices. I feel they should be discouraged.
